Daily undulating periodization was named wrong from the get-go. It is a form of programming. It's not technically a form of periodization. Daily undulating periodization is something that exercise science researchers in the United States had to have a name for and research journals because they weren't using technical sports science, terminology and a technical terminology would be like in-traum-microcycal volume intensity variations, which is like a very heavy term to lift. And it does explain what's going on well, but it's a little bit confusing. So DUP kind of went to the forefront. DUP is cool because variation is dope because doing the same thing all the time kind of sucks. And it works pretty well, but a more focused approach is almost always going to be better in the long term. So every program should be using a form of daily undulating periodization quote unquote, which is to say you shouldn't be doing the same exercises through the whole week. In most cases, you shouldn't be doing exactly the same rep and set ranges for every single day that you do. But you guys know that's just an extension of the variation principle and you probably already know that. So DUP is kind of like a mid-20 teens sort of vibe that has thankfully faded and just use enough variation to still get yourself some different looks through various ways. So you don't get super stale, but also constrain your variation so that you're still training for one thing that you need. So if you're training for hypertrophy, doing sets of five to ten, certain parts of the week, doing sets of ten to twenty, a certain other parts of the week, and doing sets of even 20 to 30, a certain other parts of the week, even on the same week or the same month, even in the same year is really awesome. It's a really good idea, but notice every single one of those is in the hypertrophy rep range five to 30. If you're daily undulating periodization gets too wacky and the variation gets really high in lowers the specificity, you actually reduce the training effect that you want, which is to be jacked because this is all about being jacked, right? I thought that was just growing muscles, but what do I know? I'm just a professor of exercise and sports science. Because we're doing hypervolume training with high intensity training. That's what FST 7 is. Every kind of training has a volume and intensity. I don't know if it's completely accurate to say there is such a thing as volume training or such a thing as intensity training. But you can have training that is of a lower volume, but higher relative effort, further beyond failure or two failure. And you can have training that has more volume, more number of sets, but each set is significantly sub-naximal, such that you're stopping three or four up-shy failure. So that effect you could have a more volume biased or relative effort, which is the technical term for intensity, bias training. Okay, we've got mobility work, which can be a thing. If there are known mobility deficits diagnosed from sport participation, potentially it's a thing, though proper weight training should resolve all of those. Cardiovascular work is usually not wise idea. In basketball, usually you want your basketball playing, and your basketball-related drills that a sport coach would manage for you to be, at least the vast majority of cardiovascular work. Why and almost all sport do you want most of your cardiovascular come from practicing the sport and practicing derivative moves from the sport? It's because if you just do cardio with the modalities, nothing do a sport like run on a treadmill, it gives you the cardio to be better at basketball or boxing or MMA, but doesn't give you any of the skills transfer. It doesn't give you any tactics. If how should athletes actually train for example, ask while athletes in the gym, they should take the core movement patterns. Pushing with your legs, pulling with your upper body, pushing with your upper body, pushing and pulling with your whole body, break those down into very simple lifts. Deficit dead lifts, stiff leg and dead lifts, the weightlifting derivatives, pulls, mid thigh pulls, hand cleans, push presses, squats, front squats, bench presses, dumbbell presses, Smith machine throws, Madison ball throws. Take all that real good stuff, pull ups, rows, etc. And you take the gnarliest compound heavy versions of those, and sets of five to ten reps. And you get that athlete stronger in that rep range, and they're going to put on a ton of muscle. When you're doing that, you're also doing some sets of three to six work, even heavier to get them stronger. And while you're doing that, you're doing some very limited work of very lightweight, explosively, to develop power, something like a Madison ball slam or something like that, Smith machine, barbell throw. As you get closer to their season, you do less muscle growth work, more strength work, and a little bit more power work. When you get to their season or very close to it, you almost completely eliminate the hypertrophy work. You just keep the strength work sets of three to six in the same compound, gnarly heavy movements, and then you expand the amount of power work that they're doing, focusing on jumps and throws and plows, so that they're peaked for that power performance, which the leapie power is the only thing that really matters in basketball. After the end of their season, you give them a few weeks off, and you bring them in, and you start to work mostly on hypertrophy again. That's actual sports science, and tiresposed to train elite athletes. The reason I delete athletes are often not trained like this, is that they are the people that choose who trains with them and how. Right, for the first set, I'll grab this handle. That's in the lower position. So that's actually really smart. If you grab the handle high up, the lever advantages yours. You will have lower internal forces to your muscles. You would give in the same amount of load on the machine. You'll have higher internal forces if you grab the handle lower because the lever advantage is no longer yours. But that being said, the different grabbing position makes the movement art shorter. And it potentially doesn't give you as much of a stretch. Listen, out, 315, you guys will notice he starts to incorporate leg drive. Leg drive is a big part of competition benching because what allows you to do is to start, you basically push a pulse of energy, using your legs, your glutes, your quads, and you push into the ground. And the way physics works with every action as an equal and opposite reaction is you get roughly equivalent pulse of energy back up through your body. Like the reason you jump is you push into the ground and the ground pushes back and then you jump, right? So you push into the ground at precisely the time that the pulse is time to travel through up your knees through your quads up through your belly and the pulse of force ends up at the same time at your chest level as the bar is leaving your chest. So what ends up happening is a lot of that energy, not all of it, but some of that energy that you pushed into the ground with leg drive is converted into vertical force off of your chest. So leg drive bounces the bar, pushes the bar, launches the bar, off of your chest, that plus your triceps, front melts and chest is where most of bench pressing force comes from. Here's the thing, probably like man, 85, 90% roughly off-hand of the force comes from your pushing muscles, chest, shoulders, triceps. Something like five and in some really, really elite people that have really worked out of leg drive, 15%, five to 15% of the force to have a completed bench comes from leg drive, leg drive is big. And so at Julius's level, if he didn't use leg drive, he might be good for in excess of 600 pounds. He might even be good for damn near 700, but 782's not gonna happen for him unless he uses leg drive. And the best way to use leg drive to develop strong leg drive, as remember, he's a giant person whose legs are plenty strong enough, no doubt without training legs, he could leg press 1500 pounds for reps, no big deal, he has to walk around at 424, his legs are strong as well. And we're not, it's not a max effort push, cause it would slide you across the bench and everything would go straight to hell. It's a little bit of a pulse, he's more than strong enough. The thing with leg drive is technique. You have to practice light benches, moderate benches, and heavy benches with leg drive to get the timing right and to get that motion right. And if you don't practice constantly for weeks and weeks and recently months and years, you won't get as much leg drive to convert into actual pounds on the bar. What that does is you ever try at home, just limpressed yourself and then push down on these muscles on these tendons. And your wrist actually comes in. So what ends up happening is if you put very, very tight wraps on your wrist, you actually get to pre-flex your wrist and a little bit of that tension for those wraps continues to be applied to those tendons. So your ability to grip a heavy load and not be limited by grip is slightly improved. But check this out. There are two reasons why that slightly is a big deal. Reason number one is if you're good for 810 pounds in the deadlift. Your grip is good for 805. You're going to miss 810 on grip. If we add 20 pounds of grip just through those straps additionally, then your grip is good for more than 810 pounds and you will succeed at the lift because everything else is already there. That's huge. The other thing is, if you feel like your grip is loosening, your body automatically through evolved brain processes starts to reduce how much neural drive, how much activation for muscles it sends to the rest of your body. So that if you feel like your fingers are slipping a little bit with 805, but everything is strong enough to pull that weight and even your hands will be able to hold on, all of a sudden, your body is producing less force. By the way, randomly I'm like a riffing on my own riffs at this point. You will hear people say that how much you can bench, doesn't impact your punching power, and all of those people are, respectfully, super politely, totally wrong. The more you bench, everything else being equal, the harder you punch someone, or to be more technical about it, the less velocity loss your fist experiences as it contacts their skull. And that means that total transfer of energy into their skull is more rapid and greater, which means their probability of falling down and not getting back up for a while is much higher. If you have someone who weighs 105 pounds and they got quick hands, they're real technical, they can get you in the jaw a couple times and it doesn't knock you out even if you're a regular person who's larger because they just aren't strong enough as soon as their fist hits, the kinetic chain moves forces back and their muscles aren't strong enough to push back through those resistive forces. And so their fist slows down really, really fast as soon as it hits your head, it doesn't transfer as much energy in, your head doesn't move as much and then your probability of getting knock it out as lower. But if your Kyle Curvee and you hit someone, they probably break into a million pieces like an NVIDEO game because the amount of force transfer is massive. That does not mean to say that how much you can bench brother is the only thing that relates to how hard you can punch. A lot of times any kind of variation is better than a totally identical training style week to This is sometimes it's really good to have some higher reps in one week and even the same exercise, lower ups and another. The kinds of stresses are a little bit different. You get more metabolic stress, more muscle soreness from the higher reps, but you get more joint and connective tissue disruption, tendons, ligaments, and the fascia of your muscles from the lower ups and heavier weight. And so if you keep on the lower ups every way, more likely to get hurt after a few weeks. Not by ton, but by enough. If you high reps all the time, you never quite get as strong as you're supposed to be. And if you do lower ups all the time, you can't really add a whole lot of muscle size. So if you alternate high and low reps week on week or within a week, Monday Thursday, for example, if you're training for some combination of size and strength, this can be a ton of strategy, especially in the off season. And then the next one and the last one for now is good fatigue management. If you are in a state of very high fatigue, your athleticism, your ability to coordinate your movements, falls substantially. And if you're very high fatigue, your connective tissues like your tendons are a little bit afraid. They only heal if you take a week or two of lighter easier training or almost no training at all. If you peak appropriately by taking a taper, everything heals and your athleticism is maximized because your fatigue comes down. If you're in a really high fatigue state and you try to yellow and go super heavy, you might have a bad time. If you're in a better fatigue state, your probability of getting hurt is much, much better. So if you manage your fatigue well, taking delodes, taking active rest phases, having appropriate tapers, not doing things at random, that's going to be a really, really good thing. I'm kidding sort The other group of people that think this are hashtag Bro split for life hashtag hardcore hashtag science and These people need to paint science based lifters into a corner of being pussies Because they like to pat themselves on the back for being hardcore warriors and since sometimes they have an intellectual and very Organ complex to science based lifters then they have to make sorts all sorts of Excusiness to themselves of why their shit is better So if I can't understand what science man is saying because I never really went to school for that long I'm gonna pretend science man doesn't train hard that'll make me feel nice the thing is Real actual science tells us what about hard a train and here we're gonna see a huge dissidence Real science in review after review after review says all other things being equal If you can recover go and closer to failure in each working set is gonna yield more hypertrophy than getting far from failure It also covers the fact that higher frequencies are almost better per muscle than lower frequencies You're probably gonna get bigger by steps training them twice a week then training them Let's say one so week Time and time again the amount of deloding that is needed for real world hypertrophy training is Usually much less than we actually think in study after study a deal at once every eight weeks or 12 weeks Accomplish as the task just fine and you do not need to deal it every three weeks or four weeks in most cases But it gets we're still quote unquote in the last little bit The amount of training volume per muscle per week like how many sets of quads? Do you need to train with to get the biggest quads you can is a number of the top end of which we have to get to reliably find and The top end of which sits almost certainly north of 40 working sets per week roughly to failure Every week for weeks on end to get your best muscular adaptations on a average per any given muscle if your whole system can recover from that sort of thing There have been multiple studies that show 30 sets of quad training is Better than 25 35 better than 30 40 Better than 35 and a few even that 45 to 50 sets is better than all the rest below Now that's what actual science says to sum it up really clearly Science says progressively burn yourself to the ground To test the very limits of your recovery and only when you start to get a little weaker and you can't keep up Do you deal load wash out the fatigue and go right back into scaling Mount Do you volume close to failure that's the reality of what science has said that is the sum of the summarization of science so far Oh, by the way Scott just to make a fine point of it So I science also tells us to get into deep stretches consistently and almost every lift we can which is a really uncomfortable right like It's the worst or what the To quote one of my friends would us down there in the deep squat that I need so badly that I'm going all the way down for it Do I get a house or some shit like if I get a free car like now? But if you're fasting that day, you're not recovering at all, you're starving. He folks, Dr. Mike here for Renaissance Pyridization, fasting. Is it a good thing for you to do? Now, a lot of people will fast for one day through the whole week. And they'll say that day is really cleansing. It's really good for them. And some people will fast the whole day at the beginning of their diet. One fast day to begin the whole thing. Both practices have some advantages, let's talk about them. So, what's the deal? Up sides of a one daily fast, whether it be once a week, or just once at the beginning of your diet, to kick start your fat loss diet. First, fasting can let you drop a ton of blood asap. When you fast for one day drinking enough fluids, obviously, you could lose like five to 10 pounds of just, just bloat just like under the skin, crap, salt water. And that can both make you look way better and sharper, and can make you feel just lighter and freer and more amazing. And if you've been stuffing your gullet with food for the last God knows how long one day of fasting can make you feel really, really cleansed, which is why a lot of the cleanses are basically fast. It can also challenge you to reduce your food focus towards the end of the day. A lot of us were so food focused all the time. They're like, what are we eating for breakfast? What about lunch? What about dinner? What about snacks? If you're fasting, well, there's nothing on the menu, and it makes you kind of re-architecture thinking a little bit, so that you focus on work, you focus on relationships, you focus on looking at birds and shit. Whatever Buddhist people say you're supposed to pay attention to in your outside, shit like that. Leaves, rustling, chipmunks, nature is metal, so don't look too close. There's no food, there's nobody coming. No one's having to help. That's it. My little not think about it. In many cases, people when they eat a bunch of food all the time, they're kind of in a parasympathetic state, kind of a state of relaxation and digestion, and that's they can make you feel a little bit drowsy and make your head a little bit fuzzy. If you are fasting, it can actually raise your fight or flight hormones just a little bit to keep you feeling really razor sharp. Believe it or not, not eating for a whole day can sometimes make you feel kind of sharper. It can give you a little bit more clarity than you're used to, and that can be quite nice in and of itself. People report this all the time with fasting. I do an idea of fasting. I feel so fucking clean and sharp and focused. It definitely happens to many people. And as a stand alone by itself for your health, at least acutely, your glucose and insulin and fat dynamics in your bloodstream, all improve like crazy. Fasting in one little day is a very healthy for your longevity, long-term health, total inflammation, all that stuff. Really starts to fix up. So definitely some acute health benefits there. And of course, because you didn't eat anything all day long, you burned a lot of fat in one day. So it's absolutely green checkmarking you on your way to your goal of being leaner. So those are all distinct upsides. However, there are downsides with one whole day of fasting, on occasion, or even just at one point. First, some people have this mental clarity experience with fasting. Other people do not. Other people just get annoyed and become very hungry. And someone's like, how did your fast go? You're like, fuck and tear, why didn't you eat anything? What did you think it was going to be? Guess that's what it was going to be like, huh? Other people say it's great. Well, like, fuck all those other people. I'm going to eat those people when I see him next time, and I'm on a fast. Okay, fine. Fasting can's happy of energy. But it's not a mystery as to how this happens. You see the food that you eat that has the energy. And when you don't eat the food, you don't get the energy. Level is destroyed and I just kind of moped around all day and kind of sit there cold and a blanket and then nothing good happens. That's totally a possibility with fasting. If it's something that's super inconvenient, you fucking hate doing it, it's not that you should feel compelled to do it because of all but it hasn't least benefits. So for example, you could be in a muscle game phase, you could be in a fat loss phase, a maintenance phase, or an active rest phase. You could be in all those phases and you'll have to design mesocycles for them specifically. If you were building a muscle game, mesocycle, you just did a muscle game one and the next one's muscle game. You just build a normal cycle in the app, you don't have to specify anything because this app is optimized for muscle game. If you're building a fat loss, mesocycle, you don't have to tell the app you are in fat loss mode. One of the interesting things that people have been requesting and eventually we're going to get this done anyway. But they're like, hey, does your diet app and training app talk to each other? The answer right now is no, and the future it'll be yes for some other reasons. But the training app doesn't actually need to know what diet phase you're in because it's auto regulation. It's algorithms for a pump, you are a sore, you are your volume, perception, fatigue, etc. It handles automatically the transition for muscle game to fat loss, so it's already going to be the best fat loss mesocycle builder that you can have. So you don't need to tell the app extra anything. Now, if you're doing maintenance in the app, you're going to want to keep it to one to three sets per exercise. And if you're getting very sore or very pumped, you're going to want to manually reduce the volume. And every single week that you do, your maintenance phase, you're going to want to click pushed my limits on your workload questionnaire portion. Because the app is just going to not add sets anywhere. You don't want the app adding sets. So for maintenance, the shortcut is just hit push my limits start with a low volume, keep the low volume the entire time. Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for Renaissance Pyrridsation, and today I'm going to talk to you about how to train when you have no equipment at all. No gym, no friends, no family, no one to love you, no wonder whispers sweet nothings in your ears you fall asleep, I got creepy. So if you don't have anywhere or with anything to train, no dumbbells, no barbell, no stretch you bands definitely know gym, what can you do, what should you do to put together a decent approach to training that can get you some kind of results, a few things. Before we get into the numbered tips, cardio is obviously still possible. So if you don't have anywhere to train, you can still jog, you can do all kinds of parkour if you want, cardio is you can definitely take walks, you can hike, so cardio is absolutely on a table, no problem at all. But what about resistance training? What are you supposed to do if you have zero weights, how do you train with resistance training? Well, turns out that there are tons of exercises that you can do that require no equipment at all or something that you don't think typically of as equipment, but you will still use as equipment. For example, you can do with no equipment at all just really a floor, you can do pushups. You can do pushups which are closer and grip and your hands stay closer to your head and you end up doing them called tricep pushups. They're like skull crushers, except for the pushup variation. You can get two chairs together and do dips in between them with your feet. On the front, on the floor, the chair dips are very popular, crunches, bodyweight squats. You can do lunges with your bodyweight, you can do scissy squats where you squat, staying on your tippy toes and you touch your knees all the way down to the ground and then come back up. You can do split squats, you can do single leg squats if you're really advanced and very strong. You can do calf races on any staircase that you have around or even some kind of ledge or curb with a stick for balance. That easy. So that takes care of a ton of leg exercises and a ton of pushing exercises. But what about anything for the back of the body? What about the pulling stuff? Well, all you need is a tree with quite a few large branches, relatively low to the ground, look round for trees, you're sure to find one of them somewhere. And then you can do all sorts of pulling. You can do pull ups. You can ratchet your feet down lower and do face pulls pulling the bar to your face to hit your delts and your biceps and your traps. You can do inverted rows on the lower branches to hit the rest of your back. You can even do inverted curls. You position yourself just under a tree branch, grab it under hand and depending on where you put your feet. It's going to allow you to leverage. You can do almost no gravity at all and you'll be able to curl your body into the branch. Doing an inverted curl, that takes care of a large fraction of your body. Pretty damn well. Not ideally, not optimally, but way better than you thought. Why don't have any equipment that needs a conduzero exercises or you can do a ton? Now you may be thinking at this point, I say, okay, great. But you've listed all the exercises and certainly there are a few more. But what if I run through all these? I mean, I got like one month or two of training, a mesocycle. Ideally, I want to switch the exercises out, but there's nowhere to go. Like you remember any equipment, you just push up as a pushup. That's not true. So that's point number three. By modifying your foot and hand positions, you can create new exercise variations that you can feed into your program so that you don't have to get super bored training with no equipment. Squats can be narrow stance, medium stance, or wide stance. Push-ups can be narrow, medium, or wide. You can put your feet up on a chair for pushups and all of a sudden do decline pushups, which are really, really hard and hit your front delts and triceps a little bit more than they hit your chest. There's a ton of ways in which to put your feet and hands into different places, including with poles, pull-ups, wide, medium grip, narrow, underhand. All kinds of options for you even if you have the bare essentials of the ground and a tree. If you cannot get access to a tree, I'm sorry. But a tree is required for part of this, or at least something you can hang onto that's at chest to eye level. And then if that's good enough, you can do rows off of it, you can do pull-ups off at center. The way you do the variations is this. You pick a variation at a time. You say, okay, I'm going to do pushups, chair dips. I'm going to do bodyweight squats, lunges, some rows and some pull-ups. That'll be a good exercise for me. A good exercise routine. Stick to one kind of grip for all those. Those are wide grip pushups, let's say. Those are wide stance squats, wide pull-ups. The theme is wide, randomly. After those exercises a few months later, get a little stale and you want to switch it up, switch over to medium grip for a lot of this stuff or narrow grip or underhand or whatever it is. Well continue to use the variations as long as they feel good and you're making progress on them. And as soon as they sort of sputter to a stop, you can then switch. That way if you have three variations wide narrow medium, even if you use one of them per month, that means you don't see the next one until three months later, which is usually long enough time for your bite at a field real fresh bottom. But typically it takes two or three months to really run out of steam at a variation, which means when you come back to wide stance squats, it could be six months or longer after you last did them and they're really going to feel different. They're going to feel new. They're going to feel fresh and you're not going to feel in comfort by this total lack of variation in your program, which sucks, right? That's what you solve with a gym. You have tons of toys to play with in just a tree and the ground is just not a lot of stuff to do, not a lot of variation. Next question number four, what do we do about progression? Because this is a tough one. In the gym with weights, progression is almost implied. You just lift more weight. But in a situation where you're lifting your body weight mostly outside or in a enclosed room with a tree in it, interesting perspective on that, how exactly are you supposed to progress? Well, got a couple of hints for you. First of all, you can add reps. Let's say you're getting really close to failure for sets of 12 in a pushup over time. So you can go to 13, 14, 15, 16. If you can do sets of 16 in the pushups, everything being equal after you're able to do sets of 12 at most, you got more muscular and stronger and healthier. Typically, we say don't go over 30 repetitions because anything much lighter than that isn't optimal. But with workouts at home or workouts on the go with zero equipment, optimal is pushed aside a little bit and possible is front and as the variable that is best. And if it grows some decent amount of muscle for us or it makes us healthier in some other way, we'll take it. So what I would say if you're training at home, try to make your lifts challenging enough by leveraging your body against yourself in such a way that you can do less than 30 reps of them per set. But potentially, you'll have to go up to 50 repetitions per set and that's totally fine because it still has muscle growth potential. And for those of you focusing your first two or three years of training, it is a lot of muscle growth potential. So adding reps is great and now we know you can add up to as many reps as we would make 50 reps for an exercise. The thing is 50 strict, good high quality push-ups is something almost nobody can do. And almost everyone that says they can do it, you actually watch them try to do it and you're like, that is the worst technique I've ever seen. That's all half reps. You're bouncing off the ground. You're not locking out your elbows. Do real push-ups and they're like, oh, I got 27 and like exactly. So even if you're in really great shape, just adding sets and reps to push-ups to pull up, to bodyweight squats, adding repetitions can go up for a long time. And if you can really do 50 reps of those movements, a lot of times you're an unbelievable shape and it's kind of like mission accomplished. Another way to take what I just said is this, if you think you're in too good of shape to get some beneficial effect from working out with no equipment, you're probably wrong. And you're probably can challenge yourself even with no equipment at all. Here's another way to challenge yourself. We're just the rest time. Typically you would do a bunch of push-ups and you would stop and rest for two or three minutes. But now because you can't put weight on your back for push-ups, you can't do the bench process. It just has to be push-ups in home or push-ups on an outdoor setting where it's just the ground, you may rest for one minute or even 30 seconds or even as soon as you get your breathing back relatively to normal, then you go again, that repeated challenge to the muscles greatly sums up how much metabolites are in the muscles, the byproducts of their efforts. And those byproducts have been linked to hypertrophy improvements to muscle growth. So if you can challenge yourself with rest times, shrinking them on the margins a little bit every time you come in, for let's say a month or two, that's going to take a workout where you do seemingly the same number of reps and make it way, way, way harder, giving you more of a muscle growth stimulus, which is really, really good. Another thing to try is my reps. Instead of resting two to three minutes between sets, half some exercises in which you do 20 reps of bodyweight squats, close to failure, it was really challenging. You rest for another five or ten seconds and you go again, maybe hitting five to seven reps a few times over and over with minimal rest that can fry you up in the best way possible, causing a lot of growth stimulus. At the gym when you go train, you may only need two to four sets of heavy resistance, barbells and dumbbells and machines in order to drive home a muscle growth stimulus. That's cool. It's really good, it's why we go lift weights because they make a challenge for us in a small amount of time. However, when you're training by yourself with no gym at all, you may have to do more sets. You might have to do four or five or six sets eventually at the end of your program, potentially in a short rest time scenario because each set isn't heavy enough to drive the best adaptations for you to get as much muscle as you can. But we add more sets, constrain the time, we end up working just as hard, except we do more sets and reps, and less weight. It takes the same amount of time as we do at the gym, but you cram more work into that and thus you're able to get a very similar comparable response in muscle growth training. So someone can train at home and say, well, I did six sets of body weights squats and it really got my legs sore. Somebody training at the gym could have done three sets and got their legs just to sore and get them to grow just as much. So there's not really a solution with this added sets recommendation. It is a solution in some sense, but it's going to require you to do more work. You guys can kind of see where this is going through adding reps, to really decreasing rest time, through introducing things like my reps, through adding sets, we're making the stimulus harder because making it hard on your body is how you make progress. Another really quick question, you can ask yourself theoretically before you start trying to put together a program that has no equipment to access. You can really ask yourself the question of how do I make the lack of equipment hard on my muscles because that's what's going to get them to grow and it's going to get you to lose body fat and get stronger and all those great things. Another thing you can do is to decrease the mechanical advantage that you're experiencing. If you're really strong in your squats from a completely flat foot, you're using your glutes, your adactors, your quads, then you're doing more than sets of 50. It's not really doing anything for anymore. What you can do is try some scissy squats. Scissy squats, essentially push your hips forward and your knees have to touch down gently and the ground all the time. That creates a crappled of mechanical disadvantage for your quads. Take your glutes mostly out of the equation and all of a sudden as far as quads is concerned. That's a mechanically disabvenant, it's harder for the quads. That's a good thing because as the quads try really hard, they struggle and that's when they grow. So a lot of times you want to ask yourself the question of how can I make this exercise more difficult on myself? Put myself in a position in which I can't lift as much weight so that I have to try harder to lift the weight that I have because the weight is your body weight. It's constant. Another one is single leg squats. Does take some balance to do and you can't hold onto a chair to do them. But if you figure out that balance, you get something to hold onto. It's a really tough exercise. All of a sudden you're very challenged in a mechanical disadvantage there is. You took one entire leg out of the equation. Stuff like that can really really really help you. Point number five in the last point for this video. The critical factors to making gains. Inside the gym or out are as follows. And these are mostly tuned for outside the gym with no equipment. You want to make sure you check a couple boxes. One you want to get close to failure often in the same workout. With heavy weights getting close to failure for one set of hacksquads in the machine in the gym. That might be a really good stimulus. But with your body weight you might have to do three, four, five or six attempt at something sets in succession in which each one of those gets you close to failure. Then you're going to have a hell of a pumping your quads, a hell of a burn and you're going to know you did something. We have to repeat the stimulus more often because we have less load. Easy fact to understand. Next one is to take limited rest time. If you're long as you're good to go, if you're not breathing heavy anymore, you're ready to do your next step. That'll save you time in your workouts. It'll also hit the muscles in a fatigue state, making things more challenging for them, thus driving up their metabolites that they produce and probably driving up muscle growth as well. If you're in a position where you're doing two or three sets of something and you're like, man, I wish I had a gym. I could really hit my back better. Try three, four, five or six sets slowly working up over time in that matter for your back training. And you may find that one, you know, would just body weight inverted rows and pull-ups. Two, three sets like I do with the machines that have you ate in the gym, they don't do much. But four or five sets, man, they really do light me up and that's providing great growth. So don't be afraid to add some volume. You can recover from it because the loading isn't that insane. You'll be totally good to go. Lastly, just to think about this, try to go in there and make things tough for your muscles. Make your muscles try really hard. Make them have to slow down during their movement. You know that last set of bench press or last rep where you're really slowing down to push it, you should take your pushups and your tricep extensions and your pull-ups so far and your training that they start to grind. Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for NSOM's Pyridization. And today we are going to talk about the five rules of abtrain. Now it might also help if you think of these, not so much as hard rules you have to go by, but really, really helpful tips and hints to consider doing your own train. So here we go. Rule number one, normal repetition ranges, apply exactly as well to abdominal training to make your abs bigger and stronger and pop out more and give you more function as these training ranges do for every other muscle group. You ask anyone in the gym, hey, I want a better chest, what do I do? So it's 10 man, I want a better bat, sets 15 to 20, whenever anything between sets a five and sets a 30 repetitions, grows the most muscle for how much fatigue it imposes, and then sets a three to six, gives you the most strength. And then when people go to abs for some reason, the game and you just need to do planks for like two minutes at a time, or like a thousand crunches. Sometimes more realistically we'll say, what's 100 crunches? Raps of 100, exactly what is it that I'm after? Some kind of weird non-sports specific, you know, strength endurance for it doesn't make any sense. Almost everyone trains their abs so they pop out more that they have ravioli abs, sets of anywhere between five and 30 repetitions and I'll even simplify it more. Anything in the 10 to 15 wrap range, just like you would for normal lifting works, best for abs, no weird wrap ranges are required. Next rule, full range of motion. For some reason, tons of people on the gym, curl like this, they do leg extensions with the full range of motion, they try some extensions, and when it comes to abs, they'll do it. So somebody's gonna meme that one for sure, I'll make it easy for you. He he he he he he he. All right, you do that. I don't know why. The abs have a huge range of motion from your hips all the way back behind you and your chest arch like this, all the way to your chest crunched and your hips all the way tucked in, a huge full range of motion, sit up and even a full range of motion crunch. There's a lot of wrong there. You don't have to do these little weird mini crunches, but if you big time stretch the abs out and you big time contract, you are gonna get more muscle growth and more of exactly what it is you're looking for from the abs. In addition to that, through a full range of motion and really good strengthening, the abs end up making you more resistant to injury through more of your daily life and any sports that you do. So people say, hey man, you need a strength in the abs to get injury proof. Let me do this. Strengthen them through the whole range of motion, you'll get way better results. Next, a huge tip to try, as far as exercise types, is the hanging knee or leg raise. Okay, so you hang, maybe with some straps, versus or something, or you do one of these things where it's one of those ab machines where you have the handle handle and you're on the pads. And what you do is you take your knees and curling your lower back, you bring your knees up towards cheese as close to your face as you could get them. And you might just come up to here at first, after you are able to do multiple repetitions where you bring the knees up close to your face and control the eccentric back down for sets of 10, which you are more, which you might want to start doing, is extending your legs out a little bit more. If you give me somebody who in one of those hanging machines can take their legs completely straighten them, lift them all the way from dead hang to all the way up, pointing themselves in a V towards the sky and slowly control that the cent for 10 reps, that person has gigantic or ravioly abs. Rule number four, eccentric control or death, I don't really mean death. What does the centric control? Once, let's say you bring your feet up in a hanging leg raise, if you just let them fall back down, okay cool, you get some good muscle growth and strength benefits from just raising them up, but you get even more benefit. Do you know what I say? Something like double the benefit from slowly lowering them back down, the eccentric lengthening phase of muscle contraction is probably more growth promoting than even the concentric that you got to bring it up. Now, we are usually in the gym really interested in check marking things and counting reps. They go one rep, two rep, three rep, and the way down at some level we don't care about, and at some level like, well, I do want the bar to go fast in the way down, so I have more energy to go on the way up. Same applies to abdominal work in its wrong. If you can quickly or at whatever speed go into the concentric portion of the exercise, if you slowly under control, lower the eccentric, it's going to cause, first of all, more delayed onset muscle soreness, which is a good sign of muscle growth anyway, and it's going to cause more muscle growth over time, more strength adaptations over time, and even this. Actually, more injury resistance over time, but you just control any centrics, a lot of times how your body prevents injury to begin with. So, if you slowly lower every single time, as well as coming up athletically, you get all of the benefits that you could do, not skimp on that big rule. With a video about five rules for fat loss cardio. Whoa boy, here we go. Rule number one is to find your best SFR modalities. What does that mean? Science man, shut up and use American words. You want ways of doing cardio methods that burn plenty of calories, but don't beat you up a ton and make you super tired, make your muscles sore and fatigued and mess up your joints. Which means the elliptical or longer distance swim or an incline walk or even just like a fast-paced walk through the neighborhood or through a park may be better more sustainable than something like a lot of step mill or a lot of plyometrics and aerobics classes where you're jumping around. For general fitness and health, that stuff is amazing. But fat loss cardio means you do it regularly for G8 to 12 weeks on end. If you do enough step milling, your legs get so fatigued that your leg workouts start to decline in quality, that you might lose leg muscle size or not gain as much. If you're jumping around, hop, skipping a lot of aerobics could beat up your joints and you need to save your joints for the lifting because that's where they really come in. So try to get a cardio modality for you that burns plenty of calories, but it doesn't beat the living crab out of you that it's got to be sustainable. Now, number two rule is to take all of those cardio modalities, the ways of doing cardio is lip-to-gulling, cline walks, women, et cetera, and do the ones most often that you enjoy the most. I know what sounds kind of lame and weird. I just want to lose fat. Forget enjoyment. Well, hold on a second. If you enjoy cardio, it's less stress overall to your day and stress is a huge fatigue booster and motivation killer. If you have cardio that you absolutely hate, it's just like planning to fail. After seven weeks of fat loss, you're like, like, quit and everyone at works like, oh no, why? Like, I just done enough cardio to where I don't want to do cardio ever again. I've retired from cardio. You have to understand limits of cardio. In most cases, much more than 45 minutes to an hour of cardio, six, ish days a week. Is the most a living human being can do without starting to really cause a lot of muscle loss and or just starting to cause a lot of fatigue from the sheer board I'm going to have an adryped to the gym and all those other crazy stuff. Cardio, in a proper fat loss plan, just gets you burning a little bit more calories than you out an average would during maintenance. And then the diet reduction and food creates most of that deficit. What you don't want to do is eat the same amount of food as normal and really crank that cardio like crazy. The fatigue is just overwhelming. It's not sustainable. So make sure you don't do too much cardio 45 minutes in an hour days. Mostly the top end on average for people. There's definitely exceptions to that. But then the deficit should come from you cranking your fats and carbs down a little bit. In most cases, that's the best approach for long fat loss. Lastly, if you do too much cardio, what you end up happening is your body can make some adjustments. Where reduces your non-exercise expenditure and not exercise activity through what genesis is the technical term. It means like your body is like, holy crap, I'm burning way too many calories. I'm not eating enough. Let's slow everything down. So like if you're sitting in a chair and there are modes over there, you normally just get up and get it yourself. But when if your kid runs over, like, hey, Billy Bob, that's your kid's name. I mean, that remote, son. Why aren't you getting it? There was no your large arm broken. You're totally fine. It's because your body's kind of secretly whispering in your ear like, hey, still you're starving to death and way moving too much. What ends up happening is during the average day, you're expenditure in total because tons of calories are burned. Believe you're not with just normal daily stuff. If you start doing less normal daily stuff, you can be doing lots of cardio and 90% of that cardio just replaces the daily stuff you're not doing anymore. That's terrible. You guys wanted to know and you asked us what is the best possible exercise to use to develop your abs according to science. Now truthfully, there is a candidacy list of the best, but there is one specifically which we're going to show you today which she was if there had to be the perfect one, this would be it. And it's called Modify the Candlestick Room. The Modify Candlestick is a very interesting exercise. Only requires you to be able to grab something behind you that's solid on what move or better yet, grab the back of a workout bench. That's all you need for this exercise. Here's how it works. The Modify Candlestick has you pulling your knees and your feet up, and then thrusting your hips off of the bench vertically into the air. That part can be done athletically and rapidly because what we want is the descent. The eccentric controlled lowering phase when you lower your legs back down, hips first, leg second, once you do that. That puts an unbelievable amount of stress onto your abs and a lengthened situation where they're being pulled apart as they go down. When that occurs, tons of muscle growth is potentiated. This is an incredibly hard exercise. So, because it's hard, there are a couple of ways for you to cue yourself in to make sure that it's reasonably possible for you to even do this exercise. And then slowly over time, you're going to be able to make it harder and hear us out. The beginner version of this exercise has you taking your knees and tucking them up as high as you can first. That shortens the lever arm of your legs and allows you to lift your hips much easier, pointing your toes into the sky. As you come down, you're going to retract your feet back down towards you as the hips lower, and then you're going to stretch your legs out separately. That's the easiest way to do it, and it's still tough. The second way to do it, which is harder, if you can do 10 solid repetitions or more in the easy way, you can move to the next way. The next way is when you start moving, you actually take your legs completely straightened and you bring them up without bending to be at all. Then you thrust your hips up, come back down, and then completely straightened lowering your leg that extends the lever arm and challenges your abs much more. The third way is almost impossible for most people to do. Pretty much only elite gymnasts and a few other folks can get away with it. If you can do 15, 20, or 25, or more of the second kind of technique, you might need to do a few of the third. That's the actual Campbell step. The reason it's called the Campbell Stick is it's completely solid and straight. That's when you have your feet totally extended, your hips completely straight. You pull back on the bench using only your upper abs. You are going to crunch your entire body like a zombie mortified, totally flat thing all the way up in a semi-circular arc. My earlier assessment of isometrics was similar to what a lot of science folks were saying. 5, 10 years ago. We used to say that isometrics were inferior for growth, compared to dynamic that is moving, concentric, eccentric, muscle contractions. It seemed valid at the time, tentatively to say they grew less muscle than dynamic contraction, but is that still true? Our isometrics back on a menu for muscle gains. Let's find out. We have a new study to look at and I'm going to rant a ton about how this fits into the overall picture and give you guys actionable training advice. The new study is the effects of long muscle length isometric versus full range of motion isotonic training on regional quadriceps the Morris hypertrophy in resistance trained individuals who in the authors are a star started cast of Dorian Vardavic Barovic Christian Saganjad Milo Wolf Milo Wolf and Bartro Klus on Dr. Lakis Karakakis which is none other than a doctor pack. Who by the way Scott has Android in his name? Oh my name? It's pretty dope. And then a Brad John Showenfeld, I don't know who that is and a Pavle Mikulich which is basically Scott this study group is like a bunch of Slavic Hitmen like the last people you see knocking on your door and Serbia and pack in Milo the dynamic duo and the Brad Showenfeld who invented hypertrophy. It wouldn't be no hypertrophy for y'all at smoke unless Brad Showenfeld was enough. So what did the study find? It had 23 participants. They trained both of their quad's six weeks straight two times a week, where they cool. But they trained each leg differently so they served as their own controls which means the statistical power, the ability of the study to find out what's going on is really high because genetics and all that stuff goes out the window. Diad and lifestyle also got the window. The only thing you're really testing is like one type of contraction versus the other. One leg did normal full range of motion-leg extensions, difficult. The other leg they put into the most stretched position or a very stretched position and had them press on that plate which didn't move so it's isometric as hard as they could for a few rounds. And so basically what happens is you're testing traditional dynamic contractions versus isometric contractions and the results were basically that both quad's grew about the same. There was some regional differences in quad growth but I think they're so small and so speculative that I'm not even having a comment down there. I hate when the we'll study insight gets taken way too far and all of a sudden we're concluding to the moon. However, the main finding that about the same growth resulted from isometrics and dynamic training is a big deal. Why is that such a big deal? My earlier assessment of isometrics was similar to what a lot of science folks were saying five, ten years ago. We used to say that isometrics were inferior for growth compared to dynamic that is moving concentric eccentric muscle contractions. Like isometric stable contractions where you're pushing and getting something and pulling and something that doesn't move we said was inferior for growth. This is because a lot of the earlier work on rodents, rats and animals of that nature and even some of the human work showed inferior muscle growth outcomes for isometric versus dynamic work. So while it was never valid to say that isometrics don't grow muscle it seemed valid at the time tentatively to say they grew less muscle than dynamic contraction but is that still true? Well this study that we just talked about by a lot of it in colleagues is just a part of a grander pattern that's been emerging in the last five years and that pattern is that a decent number of studies in the past five years have come out and essentially showed that isometric training five, five, five, ten, really, you can think about it. Isometric training causes a very robust growth sometimes comparable growth to dynamic training and interestingly enough earlier rat studies that I just read recently again, they're fun. One of the rat studies suspected that one of the reasons why the rats were not growing much from isometric rat training is basically when they hang on a little ladder with weight off their tail is that the muscles were in the shortened position and that if you got these muscles isometrically contracted in a lengthened position that you could actually stimulate more gains and we find that many of the studies recently published that show isometric severe robust for growth are also in that lengthened position because it used to be when they tested isometric severe always are almost always the shortened position curious that that prediction came out to be true. So now as of today as of 2025, 2025, it's unwise to say confidently that isometric sure a waste of time or don't work as well and it's better to say that at least at the lengthened positions in a deep stretch, isometric's might cause robust growth and be a valuable tool in training but isometrics have downsides almost all of them are practical downsides first. You know you're close to failure when your bar speed starts to slow down or the weight starts feeling really heavy and you know you're at failure when you can't move the weight anymore but what the hell does failure in isometric contractions even look like? It's really really tough to talent practical circumstances but it's a way later I'll show you how but it's tough. And the reason we concern about that is because to ensure you're recruiting lots of muscle and growing well you want to get close to failure at least in the conversation three or four upshot failure but with isometric at some point you just kind of give up pushing on the bar and how do you know you pushed it to your limits and here's the other problem that sort of dovetails in with eccentric training with concentric training on the way up on curls for example use a normal amount of nervous system activation. With eccentric training you use less so your nervous system gets less tired but your muscles get just as much growth if not even a little more. With isometric training use a ton of nervous system dry combine the fact that the isometric use of ton of nervous system drive and the fact that you don't really quite know when to quit with isometric and that is a recipe for getting very very neurologically tired for my symmetric training set for set that you would from dynamic training and that could be not great because nervous system fatigue does accumulate like all forms of fatigue and eventually it could cut your mesocycle short and make you not gain as much muscle because the training is less sustainable. In addition to that isometric's may not grow the whole muscle as evenly as dynamic contractions and they're positionally dependent so isometric's short muscle length seem to grow the proximal ends of the isometric's long muscle length seem to grow the distal end of the fibers which is to say more towards the end of your muscles away from the center of your body towards the limbs. But no isometric really grows overall that well because it's kind of one or the other bias. If you put it in the middle of the middle of the middle of the muscle but doesn't do much else for the sides are as much rap. Another hit on isometric is that they don't transfer to dynamic abilities as much. When you lift weights you do the full range of motion you get a ton of health benefits which also get a ton of strength benefits. You get a ton of mobility benefits. With isometric's you don't get nearly those benefits because what kind of sport are you isometric contracting in sports like that do exist but most sports most physical activities picking up your groceries pushing your kids in a cart pushing zombie children away from you throwing zombie children into the air and shooting them out of the air with shotguns like Scott that went real far but there's zombie children. There are real children there ghosts of ones children before but not anymore. That all requires dynamic strength and isometric's don't transfer to a rear-world shit as much. So let's some downsides. However you can implement isometric's effectively in your training plan in a few ways. First you can pause your reps under load especially in the bottom portion of lift for example with leg presses. Benchpressive and dead hang pull ups still actively contracting your quads actively contracting your pecks actively contracting your lats your lats your lats but at that very length and position can generate tons of tension. I symmetrically and can stimulate growth and is even super safe because it lowers that rebound energy you get and the probability of pulling a muscle is now much lower so extra safety and a bit of good growth can be had by doing pauses which is why for not all of my stuff but a lot of my stuff I do pauses anyway so we're already checking that box of isometric's because that's what pausing is it's an isometric contraction and now we know probably system games. The second thing you can do is use isometric long-length contractions as finisher. I hate the term finisher is mostly because I'm a person taking a asshole but let's say you're doing a last set of machine presses for chest and you are done doing dynamic reps either as close to failure as you want to be or you actually want to failure what you do here is you come down to the very stretched position but about half an inch above that so your muscles are almost at maximum stretch but completely active because they're lifting up that bottom half inch. You stay in that position and prevent the weight from clank clanking all the way down under the stretch for as long as you can or start with an extra five seconds and then next week do an extra ten and then the week after that try 15 and so on and so forth. That really timed out long long length and long duration isometric contraction right when your muscles are the most tired it's all you can do but it really milks that last bit of stimulus for muscles it's an excellent finisher that you can give a try to anytime you like it's fun it's challenging and adds loads of growth when you're too tired to do dynamic reps anymore so it's excellent for like a last set or a last set of last exercise for muscle. Shit one of the things you guys can do is do bodyweight squats at the end of heavy leg presses or hacks squats or regular squats do the two thirds my a rep style which basically you go from bottom of the squat up two thirds bottom of the squat up two thirds until you can't do squats anymore and then what you do is you fix your butt just below parallel. Scott we've done that with Tristan and a few other folks before Mr. Tristan Lee you get just below parallel and you sit in that position you're not sitting all the way down you are asked to sit at just below parallel for as a long as you can that is a narrowly long length isometric contraction and will 150 billion percent grow you more muscle it's fun and it's especially fun if you're the trainer so personal trainers for watching this you'll free to toast your clients with a setting time you like because you get to yell at them they get super hyped and motivated it's a fun challenge and the best part about being a trainer is you don't have to go through the pain if you want to go through the pain it's going to lead to more growth. I'm almost done but I have one more really important thing to tell you guys. I want to steer you guys a tiny bit away from thinking there is a particular kind of muscle contraction that you have to be emphasizing at the expense of all others there are three contraction types e-centric isometric concentric is when you're lowering load against resistance isometric is when you're holding load in place and concentric is when you're lifting and raising the load the muscle is shortening and accomplishing work. I want to trend you guys into the direction of using all three contraction types in your training why because we have good reason to believe that each of the three contraction types hit muscle hypertrophy from slightly different angles and slightly different mechanisms even and thus if you use all three you might be able to get more growth overall there was a paper back in the day in 2017 by franchy and colleagues it's titled skeletal muscle remodeling and response to e-centric versus concentric loading more phological molecular and metabolic adaptations it's a great paper I would say the muscle to do and one of the big take homes from that is that the dynamic contraction of the concentric contraction what that tends to do well actually let me start with e-centric's first because it's going to make more sense e-centric contractions grow more muscle in series which means they actually make your muscle belly a little bit longer longer fuller muscles are 100% the thing that you want in bodybuilding and in physique by doing that what they do is now that your muscle is a longer you can fill more of them in width wise and the overall volume is going to skyrocket and then you do do that a bit as well but e-centric contractions also tend to be biased towards longer muscle length portions of the muscle the distal portions of the muscle on my battery phrase that poorly so what The biggest one is that the hip thrusts accentuates the load on the glutes at the very top in their peak contracted state when you're hip thrusting through and then as you lower, biomechanically there's less and less and less exponentially less load placed on the glutes. Such that at the very bottom of the hip thrust where you're basically producing almost no force, that bottom stretch is actually the most muscle growth promoting point of any movement. So if you have the most load at the bottom stretch, you're growing a ton of muscle. If you have the same roughly amount of load at the bottom stretch, you're growing, oh, very decent amount of muscle. If you have the lowest load of the movement at the bottom, the movement is now inferior for muscle growth compared to the other two. The big difference here, guys, and this is where I want to make a big intellectual point is the difference between likelihood and certainty. There is a ocean between those things. Here's what I mean. The big mistake that so many people make in these nanny are not debates especially in the comments is in assuming that likely not natural is the same thing as definitely not natural and it's absolutely not. If someone is lean and has a fat free mass index of 25 or over, it's more likely there on gear than not knowing nothing else about them. Fact, more likely, not a ton more likely, but like 64 to more like. But people stumble when they say that someone of 25 plus FFMI is definitely not nanny, definitely not nanny because likely means functionally 51% or above. Anywhere, let's even say, let's be charitable, say 60% is likely. Certainly is 100%. And just because we're being charitable and statistically kind of nuanced was a 99% plus. You guys in the distance between 60 and 90 is really big. If you score a 60 on your last exam, your professor is going to have a chat with you about maybe changing careers. If you scored a 99% on your last exam, your professor is going to have a chat with you about an internship that he has for sure for you next month to start working in his lab. It's night and day difference. Both are on the other end of unlikely, but they're very, very different conceptual ideas. Let me give you a really egregious example that really might hit home. It's a bit out there, but as an analogy, it works. The probability, then an American soldier in the 1960s and 70s on his way to the Vietnam War would be killed and combat is qualified in a CIA probability scale as exceedingly unlikely or very unlikely. Extremely unlikely. About 2% chance. There were something like 60,000 killed an action in Vietnam and literally multiple millions of people served in the conflict. 2% chance of death in Vietnam. It's true to say it is a very unlikely for any soldier going in Vietnam, but they were going to die. True. But imagine telling someone on their way to Vietnam, that they definitely won't die. Our problem here, which is why I'm watching this video, is that you want to do more push-ups, but lately in the last several months you haven't been able to add a single notch or just one push-up per several months, nothing great. You want to do more push-ups. Maybe it's, you know, you've been doing around 30 reps, but you want to be able to do around 35 reps or push-ups in a single set. Maybe it's you haven't been able to go from 15 reps to anything bigger in like a year. Maybe you're going from zero ever push-ups to finally your first push-up. We got all the answers in here for how to make the changes. And when I say conventional attempts have failed to produce results, I mean stuff like first of all, just training hard. As if you go on YouTube comments, you go on much of social media, and you ask, hey man, like, is anyone having any push-up tips? How do I get better push-ups? And someone's like, just train hard, bro. Like, hey, thanks a lot. I'll go try that. You go try it. It doesn't work. A lot of times it does. In this case, for you, it hasn't, which is why I still have a problem. You've already tried doing different grip positions for push-ups. Didn't seem to help. You've tried weighted push-ups. It's a common helping thing, a helpful suggestion. You've tried sets of one to two push-ups at a time. If you've only been able to do a few push-ups, and people say, I'll just do sets of one to two. You've tried eccentric push-ups where you lower yourself with your own power, but then you get on your knees to come back up. They can make getting when more quality to work possible when you're just not very strong in push-ups. And you've tried partial push-ups, which is when you push up to a mat or something and you don't have to go as deep as normal, it essentially lifts your upper body off the ground, your feet are still on the ground, so the angle is lower, so it's easier. You've tried these things individually, and they seem to have not produced results. So you want to improve your push-up ability and you want to take a serious attempt at. It means your chest shoulders and triceps are going to want to get bigger. First, why? Because a lot of the reason that people can't get better at push-ups is they've gotten very good, technically it push-ups, their nervous system has integrated their ability to do the push-up motion very athletically and very well, but they're just kind of out of raw material as far as forced generating capacity of muscle to do anything better. They're like, not a bodybuilder, I just want to do more push-ups and it's like, you ever see people that can do a lot of push-ups? They generally have pretty stacked, chush shoulder triceps and they thought by axe. The second phase is for you to develop what's called basic strength and solid technique in push-ups, which is really, really important because yes, you could have big and strong muscles, much like myself, of course. But you have to practice making sure that those muscles are performing as well as they can for the task of doing push-ups. While you may use a variety of exercises to build your pecks in this first phase, the exercise is used to get your pecks ready to give you the best push-up result possible, maybe at least exercises that biomechanically load the pecks in a similar way, or the technique moves your body through a similar way, it's just more specificity. And lastly, you're going to want to take a little bit of a peaking phase, which usually lasts just a few weeks, maybe a month, to peak for push-ups specifically because you don't want to try to peak when you're not super ready. If you're a beginner watching this or if you're a media watching this if you're an advanced person who coaches intermediate Watching this There could be some gems in here that you could avoid and it'd be really really awesome because then you could do a good job at coaching people and It coaching yourself without making these mistakes. So what are they? I have six that make the list the first one is Very very ultra common and it is kind of Almost everyone makes this at some point when they transition from being a beginner To an intermediate one of the big sort of inflection points there is you can no longer make the same gains So for example beginners can just add five pounds to the bar and still do sets of five for like Months and as an intermediate you may try to do that sort of thing and typically where it took you three or four months until you just got tired I needed a break you were still hitting PRs as a beginner now after two months You're not tired. You don't need a break, but you physically have stopped making PRs because your body doesn't adapt as fast anymore It's more challenging to adapt you've already adapted quite a bit you're an intermediate welcome and you have to now realize that beginner gains are gone Some people will program hop Try to find those beginner games again, but they're gone forever Well, unless you stop training recess in all of your games then you can repeat beginner gains But it's really just getting the gains backcains so a lot of people will Just assume people the assume that they progress just as well and Continue to run into high levels of fatigue and shitty caps platoes and their PRs and what they have to understand is that the same rates of progress are not rounding more in its time to adapt Here's one way in which you can adapt if you like to run two months or Eight weeks of successive training until you take a deal at our break As a beginner, you used to do that and you'd put Five pounds on the bar every single week and you could just hit PRs PRs PRs all the way through Now you can't do that anymore try this every other session put five more pounds on the bar and every other session just do the same reps You did last time with the same weight just try to get the technique a little bit better better Mind loss of connection a little bit better external technique and really high quality reps Right, so you have a challenge week and a mastery week a challenge week and a mastery week and that way You only progress Instead of all let's say 40 pounds to the whole process You may progress only by 20 pounds, but it's actual progress because remember 40 pounds is an illusion You can't progress like that anymore in two months because you would hit these mega platoes You get Point three is you want to try to split up the same or similar muscle groups such a way that they're trained symmetrically through the week and there's enough time between them to recover more. So for example if you want to train chest in a four way split or four day split rather it's cool probably to train chest Monday and Thursday or Tuesday and Friday but if you train chest Monday and Tuesday you run into two problems. Problem number one is that you're supposed to be recovering and growing on Tuesday from the stimulus you put into your chest Monday but you're interfering with that growth and recovery by training it hard again. And secondly when you're supposed to be training hard on Tuesday for your chest you can't because you're tired fatigue to sore and less able to produce force and thus present an overload in a stimulus because you're fucked up for Monday. It makes sense no way that you slice it. Now if you reduce the volume sufficiently of each one or at least the Monday you can go back to back then what the fuck do you do with the rest of the week? You generally want symmetry spreading muscle group support as much as possible. Lastly and this is fancy but you guys get the fancy because this is my honest honest predestination we're trying to get you all the science is you want to avoid narrowly muscle group overlap that isn't obvious but will screw up your ability to have a good training stimulus.
