Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for Renaissance Pyrridsation and today's video is about how to use machines in the gym best to grow muscle and get the most optimum training that you can. Here's the deal. Machines can work super, super great for training. But while three weights automatically conform to your body structure and position, if you're five foot one versus if you're six foot six, the bench press, the row, the squat, they fit your body no matter what because your body determines the trajectory. Yes, some taller people with red limb ratios have trouble with some lifts, but a lot of times simple corrections can totally remediate. Machines are built for a specific range of heights and often even not very well. And the machine does not have sometimes any degrees of freedom or very limited one. So this is a big reason why sometimes a lot of machines are really tough to get a good feel out of to get a very good stimulus to fatigue ratio to get a good tension pump burn while minimizing joint and connective tissue stress. However, we do have tips for you here in this video how to get the most out of your machines if you train yourself amazing. Welcome, this video will be awesome for you, but especially if you're a personal trainer and you train clients, this can really help you optimize your use of machines for clients of all different shapes in size. Remember, the machine is still limited and especially shitty machines can only be optimized so much, but working with whatever machines you have, you can do better and you can do so with at least five of the following tips. First, range of motion really is good for muscle growth, especially range of motion at the stretch. So you can set up a lot of machines to get that range of motion out of them. For example, if you have a chest press machine, a lot of times the back pad has a selectorized moving implement into which you can set the back pad to be recessed back or progressed forward. If the implement only come down solo, you can push the chest pad up and all of a sudden you can go deeper. If that pad does not exist, which you can do, just take one of those like purple yoga pads, which if you don't know what that is, literally Google, purple yoga pad, and Amazon will show you all the options. It's the purple yoga pad when it comes up on Google Image Search. Watch GBT's do all this by the time the video is out and people are like, what's Google Image Search? Goddamn, the young ass tick-tockers, you take the yoga pad, you put it behind you, and all of a sudden that's two extra inches for your range of motion, which is something you can probably benefit from in other areas of your life. Booting. Shhh. I'm here all day folks. Another idea is many hamstring curls, specifically lying leg curls, they just don't have that stretch at the bottom for your hands, but courtesy of Mr. Trevor Fullbright, who runs our team full-round for him for us. You put a yoga pad below your thighs right on top of the machine, lay down on it, and all of a sudden that's two extra inches that you are moving in a very stretched, highly loaded position for your hamstrings. It can make that machine and many others a ton better. Of course, leg press is the quintessential one here. For leg presses, pattern to the lower back prevents your back from rounding and increases the range of motion. So if you lean the back pad as far as it goes, put some yoga pads or mats under your lower back, that can take a shitty leg press or a decent leg press and make it into a good leg press or even a great leg press. Next, when you are training on machines, the machine is not going to be conducive in most cases to rapid ballistic concentrics. Especially if you're a power lifter or someone from a strength training background, it's okay to push the dumbbells up on a dumbbell press really fast. Totally cool. But on a machine a lot of times you'll get more out of the movement if you don't know so much think about slowing down the machine but being controlled with it. Really having that control, because the machine already puts you into a specific arc, controlling and really trying to connect with your muscles, maybe a much better use of your time than actually trying to be ballistic with. Number three, this is huge. If you get a machine and you try it for a set and you're like, ah, feels off, don't just leave. Experiment with different grip positions, with different foot positions, with different body positions to see how you can maximize the use of that machine. You can even do the set to set to set, as you warm up. You warm up with a wide grip on this pulled-down machine thing and you're like, you're up with an air grip, second set, you're like, you warm up with a medium grip and you're like, okay, okay, okay, that feels best. My joints feel pretty good. I can feel my last stretching, now we're in business. What you're going to be doing as you're warming up and even as you're using the machine over several weeks is playing with your position of your body and every all the limbs that you're moving and even the settings and the machine like moving the chest pad and the butt pad and everything is you're going to be looking for the stimulus to fatigue ratio, proxies, things like, does one of the positions get you better pumped than the others? Does it get you better tension? Does it get you better burn the target muscles and is one of the positions or some of the positions better for your joints and connective tissues? Maybe you set the skull crusher, we're trying something you machine on a certain setting and every time your elbows are creaking like, how, how is a stupid? If you raise the seat all of a sudden you're in their jamming and you're elbows feel great. That's some stuff to look for instead of just abandoning and being like, this is a terrible triceps machine. Maybe it is, but you haven't really given it to diligence yet. Point number four is to be open-minded about set and rep range and modality possibilities for machine. Yes, if you lie down and do two sets on a hamstring curl for sets of 10, you may not get a whole lot of anything out of it and be like, this is a fucking stupid waste of time. I could do two sets in a stiff leg, I'd done a good morning and my hamstrings would be that for five days, true. But hold on a sec, that machine also does a fatigue you much and it doesn't take as long to do a set of leg curls as it does to set up, walk out, do a set of stiff leg and other walk back in, sure shit you don't have to load weights on the bar, just select rise. So now I'm a leg curl, try three or four or five sets. Try a different modality. Like a myorat match. For example sets of 10, but every time it's a set of 10 and if you get two tired, you set of 10, do as many reps as you can and then finish up the set with as many reps as are left over. First set of 10 really close to failure. Second set you get eight, rest for a few seconds, then get the other two, that's 10. Next time you do six, rest two, rest two, that's 10 total. That multiple times bringing close to failure is nothing you lever need out of most freeway movements because they're more stimulative, but on a machine that's not so stimulative you can really really milk it out. And the other thing is to be open-minded about repetition ranges. You know, sets of 10 on a stiff leg are a bit amazing, but on a hamstring curl sets of 10 could be like, I'm just not contracting the muscles for long enough to do a whole lot of anything. Try sets of 15, try sets of 20. I'll have a sudden that provides great variation, something different than you do with your stiff leg and leg abud lifts, but at the same time it's zapped your shit and it works. Lastly exercise order. You may use leg extensions for example as a first exercise and it's like not a lot going on here. I don't just get tired and I'm tired for my squats, but if you try leg extensions after squats or leg presses as a, and I hate to use this chair, this is a bullshit term. Finish or just a second or third exercise, you can find that okay, wow, now that I'm warmed up now that I feel stronger now that my joints are good, I can really milk the last little bit of burnout of my leg extensions. So then you wouldn't use leg extensions as a prime mover, sorry, as a first exercise, really big movement, but you wouldn't write them off completely either, you would say, hey, they're great, but maybe as a third movement or as a second movement in my quadriceps routine. At the very end, once you've done your due diligence, you've tried all these things. Some machines you'll be able to get a lot out of you. Like, oh my god, think I did these things because man, this leg press now I can really get a ton out of. Other machines you'd be like, it's a fine machine to do for a month's cycle or two with all the alterations that I've been doing, but it's never going to be a rock star machine. So when we say specialization, we mean putting more focus on something to make it grow more. What does that mean we're actually doing as far as program design as concerned? First of all, we have to check the box of specificity. That means that we choose exercises and modalities, like straight sets, down sets, drops, etc., repetition ranges that preferentially stimulate the target muscle. We're not trying to do B plus or C plus answers. We're trying to do A and A plus answers. Don't worry, we'll have ways of getting around the fatigue problem there where you can. Group anything right anymore, but it has to be a thing you recognize objectively. If I want a bigger muscle, I've got to train it all earlier, so it has more energy with which to be trained and gets better results. Frequency. Almost always, slightly higher frequencies, favor short-term hypertrophy results better than slightly lower ones. So yeah, you could train your forms once a week and get pretty good results, but you'd get better results with two sessions and probably better results even with three. So anytime you're trying to prioritize on any muscle forms, included, a slightly higher frequency is absolutely something to keep as a mainstay of your intervention. This is definitely something that works almost every time. It's kind of like, when you decide to bulk up, you eat more food, that's one of the big check boxes. This is similar one, similar in power. Every single one of those sets, that means every single one of those sets is technically junk volume for your grip, so that it makes your grip tired for when you have to do form training later. Number one, just straight up better technique. There's a way to lift weights that just kind of lifts them from 0.8 to 0.3 like in the deadlift. You just pick it up and it works great. But there's a way to lift with a bit more nuance where you have the kind of technique that reduces injury risk, probabilistically by at least a small margin. Here it is. When I deadlift, I started deadlifting. I made try to tight lower back. I never had a rounded lower back and was ratcheting up the reps. That took my lower back. A little ding and ping kind of injury rate and just plummeted it to the ground. Retracted shoulders on pressing movements, for example. You leave a shoulder flat out like that. Tons of football players get tons of shoulder injuries in the gym from bedspersoning because they don't know how to bench press properly. In powerlifting, shoulder injury is actually very rare because you've retracted just scapially. You're going to hear more joints are deep back there and safe away from a ton of weird instability and all of a sudden when I started doing that, I just stopped getting hurt. In high school, I would bench like a normal person and I just got hurt shoulder several times. It even was just like a year and a half of lifting and then I had a power lift or teach me how to do a proper archer contraction and I swear to God, I never hurt my shoulder ever again on the bench press, ever. Big deal. I highly recommend just pay attention to technique. No what technique is more likely to be injurious, make sure it's stable and reduce that injurious technique and introduce the technique that gets you hurt less. Number two, controlling the eccentric. You want to hurt your knees. It's really hard to do it in the gym. The gym's a safe place, but you want to probabilistically increase the potential for you hurting your knees, dive by your squats, dive by your lunges, go quick into the hole, rapidly descend with the bench. Those high forces in that plyometric transition, that's the highest force you'll ever expose yourself to and in a stretched position. It's I don't want to say a recipe for injury, but if you really want to put a fine point on it, yeah that's a good way to try to get hurt. So what you do instead is you control the eccentric. I don't mean like forever. I mean even on a cable curl instead of going, oh like that, just going like that. Even a one second, some semblance of control, but ideally two to three seconds, is going to get you tons of eccentric damage and tons of eccentric mediated growth, which is huge by the way, and will make you huge, but it also really, really, really does reduce the risk of injury. So that's something I started to doing. My injury risk started to doing and my injury risk went down precipitously. How's that for a big fancy big brain word? Number three, D-loading on time. Then you are going to perform probably several months of hypertrophy work on those limiting factors. So limiting factors. Here's how I would do this. You may disagree with it. You may go slightly your own way, but this is a method I think works pretty well. You can do your squats for you. Just kind of hip stop moving or do you miss them kind of bent and rounded over? Right. It's very hard and are you when the reps get harder starting to cant believe or over and round over in your back or in the reps are getting harder, are you able to stay upright and it's just like your legs feel like you're grinding through. But if in the hole you can't budge out of the hole, that means the quadriceps which are the primary and the only knee extensors humans have to some extent, that's pretty true to a large extent, then really knee extensions limiting factor and you sort of need bigger and stronger quads if you're missing your squats in the hole. If you're missing your squats or have trouble with your squats at around or maybe just above or below parallel, but you're upright the whole time, it's just overall strength. That position of right around parallel with a squat is actually like the mechanically most difficult position, right? Just add or below parallel or just above parallel depending on a few factors. So if you're going to be completely well balanced with your knee extension strength and your posterior chain strength, your ability to push against the ground and your ability to lift your back up after it's bent over, if those are balanced, that's probably where you're going to miss your squats. So then there's nothing ending off balance. You're really have limiting factor, you just overall strength needs to come up. And that's a really straightforward problem we know how to fix. And then lastly, if you're breaking if your squat, you're missing it kind of around parallel or even just above, but you're missing it because you're starting to really round it over and that tends to reduce a ton of your ability to drive through the floor, then it's probably the your posterior chain is a limiting factor. Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for Renaissance Periodization, our training modality video for today is about supersets. He doesn't that sound super? Anyway, what the hell are supersets? They're actually two types of supersets. We're only talking about one here. There is a type of superset called an antagonist muscle superset, or an unrelated muscle superset, where you do muscles, one set for a group of muscles, and then you're next superset, with no rest between, is for an intentionally un-involved set of muscles. For example, you do your chest and triceps with clustered bench, and then immediately you go into inverted rows, and you do your back and biceps with rows. That's a superset, yes, but it's not the time we're talking about here. Those are antagonistic, or unrelated supersets. They're designed to maximize how much total work you get in a minimum time in the gym. They're not ideal for hypertrophy because if you do clustered work, and then you do right after your back work, a lot of times especially if you're bigger and stronger, if you don't rest between sets, the systemic fatigue is so massive. It prevents you from doing a lot of good work on whatever that second set is, that second exercise, and then maybe it's not ideal. Great time, save versus a lot of you can still use it, but since this is a really advanced hypertrophy stuff, we're only talking about today, agonist supersets. That is, you do an isolation movement for the target muscle. Let's say skull crushers were triceps, and then right after you do a movement that is compound, but is still limited by the triceps. Something like an overhead dumbbell press or something like that. So skull crushers put the bar down, get up, overhead dumbbell press. Okay, that way your triceps get a decent stimulus in that first exercise, but then when they are already fatigued close to failure, they are the limiting factor, you do a compound exercise, you used to be that overhead dumbbell presses are for front delts, good stimulus, and triceps, great stimulus. But now because your triceps enter that exercise is almost dead, and your front delts enter completely fresh, more or less, every single of the five to ten reps you'll grind out of those dumbbell presses will be your triceps are close to failure, close to failure, and we know from tons of research and theory that if we train very close to failure, more that magnifies the stimulus a ton. It essentially lets us, these agonist supersets, take a muscle, and train it with an isolation and a compound, but the effect is like double the isolation. Really awesome way to use compounds to extra train that muscle that we want. So what you do is set for whatever isolation muscles you want, and then with no rest generally or as long as it takes triceps to just an exercises, do a compound exercise in which that muscle is involved in this way, way, way ideally the limiting factor. What are the upsides to train? So of course after words, so you see some skull crushers, dumbbell press, rest, and normal amount of time, and then hit it again. Skull crushers, no rest, dumbbell press, rest normal, and then go again. Here are the upsides. First of all, you can get an amazing stimulus, especially for muscles that generally have compound exercises that can train them really well, and maybe don't respond as much to isolation movement. So for example, if you do lying or seated hamstring curls very well on a good machine, that hits the hamstrings even though it's isolation so well. Well, fuck, you don't need any supersets. What does that mean for your quads? Could your quads be bigger? If you did other things instead of just high bar squatting? And at some point, the question was answered, yes. And then what the hell is I supposed to do? This in power lifting and in strong man, these lifts are everything. But at bodybuilding, there means to an end. And if you can get to that end in a more efficient means, you've got to drop the ego off at the door. So here's how I came to change my ways. At first, here's what I did. I did not abandon compound lifts. But I did remove the ones that had the lowest stimulus to fatigue ratio as for hypertrophy for me, low bar squats. They're designed to give you advantage and leverage, not disadvantage and leverage. Just advantages what you want for growth oftentimes are really focused in a one muscle. And advantage lets you lift more weight, but it really just lets you lift more weight. So you could good at that. Your bones and tendons grow and stuff. That's cool. But as far as hypertrophy, you're actually getting less hypertrophy from an even higher workload and even higher risk of acute injury. No more low bar squats. I stopped doing racked eggs or floor beds. And every time I would deadlift, I would do deficit deadlifts. Because they expanded the range of motion. I didn't have to use as much weight and the stimulus to my glutes, to my back, was much, much bigger, whereas the fatigue was comparable. And so that's really, really good. I added in more paused lifts. That's what I was a really big deal. I had been through some injuries. And I'm like, I'm mostly gonna pause almost all of my lift now because I don't see a downside. And I see an increase in safety. And I think that's a really good. So I started pausing my lifts and I chose longer ranges of motion lifts, like cambered bar rows and set of regular rows, cambered bar benches and set of regular benches, deficit deadlifts, good mornings to the rack and things like that. I also started incorporating more Smith machine variations just for something different to do that wasn't barbells. Another thing is stability, you can really connect with your chest when you're pressing on a Smith in a way that you sort of can't with a barbell, not barbell bench or an incline as good and I'm not taking anything away from him. But sometimes just variation on Smith, you can really connect with your muscles better because you don't have to do the cognitive work, the neural throughput work, of actually stabilizing the barbell to nearly the same extent. And these Smith machine lifts let you bias targeting of muscles in a way that barbells can't, for example. High bar squats are amazing for your quads. But if you want your quads to grow even more per any unit of time that you spend working on them, if you get into a Smith machine and especially if it's a slanted Smith machine where the slant goes forward as it goes lower, if you push your feet a little bit in front of where that barbell would land on the slant, you can maintain way, it's essentially completely upright upper body posture and your knees go way over your toes at the bottom end, which means the fraction of load and the stimulus and thus growth that is given to your quads in that feet forward Smith machine squat is higher and the fraction that's given to your lower back and your glutes and your mid back is lower. But like when I do squats, it's a quad movement for me. And so I started doing these kind of feet forward squats and I was like, damn, these hit and I'm like the same fatigue I would be from regular squats except my quads have one and a half times more stimulus and they're getting bigger. Increasing your pull-up can be a big deal both repetitions and just being able to do more pull-ups with rate attached. It's a big deal. A lot of folks want to know how to be able to do more pull-ups where to get better at. One are having their pull-up and we have some simple tips. We have eight tips for you today. Eight improvement tips that you can use ASAP to improve your ability to do pull-ups. So first is to standardize your technique. One of the things I suppose I'm not a big fan of is when people are very serious about increasing their pull-up ability and the way they'll set up for pull-ups is they'll jump and grab the pull-up handle and start going. Where you put your hands when you jump is going to vary considerably, making every single set for pull-ups slightly different and that doesn't allow your body to really improve or sort of impose its motor learning effect on the ability to pull-up. If you standardize everything, putting your pinkies and hands in the same place every time, wrapping or unwrapping your thumbs, doing the same range of motion preferably for a deep stretch and all the way up to at least the chin, then you start to do that sort of pull-up over and over and over and over and yes, well, your ability to do pull-ups is in large margin determined by your general pulling strength and how much you weigh, a big part of being able to do pull-ups is just the neural efficiency and the technique of doing pull-ups and your body gets really, really good at stuff you practice all the time. So if you practice the same way or a very similar way over and over and over and over, you standardize your pull-up technique, that can make you really, really good at doing that technique. And since that technique is a pull-up, you'll be getting better pull-ups being able to do more max weight or maximum reps. So that's number one. Next, you want to spend time in the target rep range for doing pull-ups. This is a short-term strategy that works for a few months. Eventually, more advanced stuff will have to be imposed, but we'll do that video next week. But a lot of folks, you know, if they want to improve how many pull-ups they can do for reps, you'll see them doing some interesting stuff as far as repetitions, train in the rep range you want to improve. So if it's maximum number of pull-ups that you want, at least in the short-term, do slightly weighted 5 or 10 pounds on the belt or unweighted or barely assisted pull-ups, stay close to your body weight and do reps sets close to failure to be able to good at, for example, sets of 10. If you're pull-ups around 10 reps max, you want to be able to be good in that rep range and training that rep range all the time is the best. If you train, for example, with a huge amount of weight and do sets of 3 to 6 repetitions, that will make you very strong and pull-up, but if you transition to taking that weight off and seeing how many pull-ups you can get maximum, which is sort of what you were going for all along, this is going to be a weird transitional time where you're doing reps and you're body English is different because the weight doesn't pull you the same, your legs start moving a lot, it's a strange thing. You might sort of get tired and crampy earlier, even though you feel like you have a lot of strength. So train in the rep range you want, at least for a few weeks, then I promise you'll have a better result. If you want the best one or end in the pull-up, basic strength is what a train and that sets of 3 to 6 repetitions with progressively more weight, eventually you do some doubles and singles, take a little easy workout and then try to do the biggest pull-up on around that you can after that. Next, this is a big deal, do pull-ups more often if you really want to get good at pull-ups. Even if not all of the workouts are super hard. For example, you could have a situation where you have three workouts per week in which you train pull-ups. One of the workouts can be relatively heavy with assistance or sorry, the opposite of assistance, weight that you hang off in yourself with some pull-ups after with no weight. Another workout maybe that could be Monday, Wednesday could be you do lots of pull-ups with no weight and then assisted pull-ups. So they're actually lighter than normal, we'll get extra high volume and that's really good. And then Friday you think to yourself, okay, if I do another hard pulling workout with lots of pull-ups, you know, Friday it'll be too much, but hold on a second, you might not have to do that. You might be able to do a workout based mostly in rows or some other parts of your back that don't really overdo the pull-up movement, but you might take either at the end of the workout or at the beginning or somewhere in the middle, probably beginning or end, my preference is for the beginning. It's to do just a couple of sets of two or three repetitions in the pull-ups. Let's say you're able to do 10 to 15 pull-ups. On that Friday a couple of sets of two to three reps in the pull-up can allow you while focusing by the way on a ton of awesome technique. That can allow you to get one more technical practice session. We're sort of treating the pull-up like a power lift. Like you would do a very light deadlift to practice that technique of the deadlift even though you can't do more heavy-deads because it fatigues you too much the same principle applies to pull-ups. A lot of people the way they get good at pull-ups is they just do pull-ups like five days a week or something. That could be a really good way to do it. It could be a bit overkill, it could be some optimal, but what they're getting right at least in that part is they practice practice practice doing the pull-up. What I don't want you guys to do is really really give a shit about how many pull-ups you can do and then do one time a week you have pull-ups in your workout. Even though you can do sets of 10 to 15 no problem. I understand that if you can only do one or two pull-ups maybe that max effort is really only for one day of the week. You should do some serious pulling and maybe in one of those when it's too much and it's too much volume to do a lot of really high effort pull-ups maybe you can do a couple of doubles and pull-ups just to be able to get a little bit more time spending ingraining that pull-up technique and then all of a sudden you're just really really really good at pull-ups. Now that my legal stuff has taken care of, let's talk about how sleep hygiene works, how you can get better sleep and some examples of how I get my good sleep with my phenomenal life that I love so much. Sleep is a big deal for games. Study after study show that if you don't get enough sleep, your ability to grow muscle suffers tremendously. Your ability to gain fat is boosted tremendously. And even if you're a caloric deficit, your ability to lose fat is severely hampered. Which means that if you're on a weight loss journey in a caloric deficit, if you don't get enough sleep, you might be losing muscle and not fat. I'm not kidding. It's a real thing. So let's talk about how to get good sleep. I have 11 tips for you today. This really is kind of a really big deep dive. So don't listen to this before you go to sleep, otherwise it's going to be boring and you're going to not off. But if you are still here with us, put in your headphones, look around you, the world is beautiful. Let's talk about sleep. Number one is to have a consistent week, week, week, week, week, week. Number one is to have a consistent sleep wake schedule. Going to bed at roughly the same time every day, roughly I'll get to that in a second. What that means, even weekends can strengthen your circadian rhythms, improving your sleep quality majorly. If you go to bed and wake up at roughly the same time on most days, the reinforces your biological clock, which is an internal thing that happens in your brain, it makes sure you're secreting melatonin, which puts you to sleep at the right time, and it makes sure you're secreting cortisol in the morning to wake you up at the right time and not secreting about your cortisol and your supposed to go in a bed or melatonin when you're supposed to be waking up. If you can get into that habit, even over a few days, it really does improve sleep quality. And the real-world tip here is to pick realistic times. Some people do this thing, like, how do I go on a sleep at 8pm every night or 9pm? No, you're not, my f***er. That's what all the good shows are on. That's when Netflix is like, hey, you should probably watch this and you probably will. So instead, pick some realistic times for many people that's between 10, 11 and midnight or clock, get your 7 and a half to 8 and a half hours, wake up at that time, roughly every night. Now, plus or minus 30 minutes, even plus or minus an hour is not a big deal, but the less variation you can have the better. Is it okay to party every now and again, and get crazy on the weekends and not sleep? Yes, you're living life. It's no big deal. But there's a very big difference between once every two weeks pulling an all night or going a bed at 2am and doing that like three days a week. That second one is going to mess with your gains because your sleep will be highly subopt. Me personally, I'm usually in bed by about 11pm. Sometimes this late is midnight. On the weekends, I tend to be high in edible marijuana, which I mostly take earlier on the day, so I'm not super high by the time I go to bed, but weed makes me very, very tired and groggy, so I'll often go to bed even earlier on weekends, which sounds like I'm not having any fun in my life. Yes, this is a cry for help. Now and again, again, you can go crazy, have an all night or it just can't be all the time. Number two tip. Morning, sunlight exposure. And actually, preps you for being sleepy or night, even if the sunlight was delivered in the morning. That's how that works. So it's really, really awesome. Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for Renaissance Pursation. And today's BS video topic is that insulin makes you fat or does it? Let's get into the details. What's the claim here? Well, insulin signals fat storage. And thus you should avoid insulin-secreting foods, all of which at the top end are carbohydrates. And this is the carbohydrate insulin model of obesity. People eat too many carbs. Insulin is secredent on moss. Insulin is lipogenic. It leads to the creation of fat stores. And it also removes carbohydrates from your bloodstream. And then you don't have anymore. So you're hungry again. So eat more carbs. And then just get stored as fat. And so on, the mayoring around continues to be way 600 pounds. You have no idea what happened. All I ate is one apple. You tell yourself that you sound a lot better when you say that. There is some theoretical support for the idea that this might be the case. Yes, insulin does in fact trigger lipogenesis. It does trigger the creation of fat. It absolutely does shuttle nutrients from the bloodstream into fat cells, where they are used to build more fat molecules. The part that usually folks leave out is that insulin also shuttles nutrients into muscle cells. And many other cells of your body that also build muscle. Yes, get to that in a bit. And insulin absolutely can under some circumstances cause so much of your blood glucose to be removed from the blood into the cells that you get a radical rebound, hunger spike. And it causes you consume even more carbohydrates building that positive feedback loop to get you to 600 pounds. Now, that is precisely where the support for this idea ends and the theoretical problems actually begin. First, if you are not in a calorie surplus, that is eating more calories than you burn. It is very difficult, perhaps impossible for insulin to create net increases in your body fat and body weight, where would it get that stuff from? Insulin doesn't seem to reduce your physical activity levels. So if it can't tip the scales of thermogenic balance, not really sure how it's supposed to build more net tissue, the only way to get to 600 pounds is to eat a lot of food, which insulin doesn't really itself have an effect on. Insulin in healthy people plays no favorites as to which cells it transports nutrients into another problem. So insulin is actually very anabolic towards muscle tissue. It helps muscle grow and it helps fat grow. It helps everything grow, but the key to that growth in the long term with muscle and with that is a caloric surplus. So you've got to eat more food than your body needs in order to make insulin this very powerful mediator of actual gains. Now, if you say to yourself, look, carbs are very lipogenic and the insulin that comes with him is part of the problem. Every time you eat carbohydrates, your body secretes insulin, the carbs cause fat gain, the insulin cause extra fat gain, the two of them combined are like the Batman and Robin of if Batman and Robin instead of fighting crime just made people fat. So you say to yourself, well, I like the old 1960s Batman and Robin just fine, but I'm going to eat more fats and fewer carbs. I'm even going to load low carb and I'm going to have a lot of dietary fat and very little dietary carbohydrate to prevent the insulin or carbs should being turned into fat. And then you think about that for about three seconds longer and you think, why would my body have to turn the carbs into fat? If it just got fat in the diet, it could take that fat in pretty much directly put it into fat cells and make me fat that way. And then you would answer that question in the affirmative, yes, actually, would do that. So it turns out when people do low carbohydrate diets to try to reduce the impact of insulin and carbohydrates on adiposity and the creation on the lipogenesis creation of fat, they have absolutely succeeded only to replace that carbohydrate with fat in their diets. And now that fat directly goes into fat cells and just makes you fat. Requiring no conversion I might add and it makes you just as fat to eat fats as carbs. This is a matter of fact by small margin, fat is more lipogenic than carbohydrates. So the low carb diet where eat lots of fats, that doesn't seem to work all that at well. Now, those are the theoretical problems. What problems do we run into when trying to say insulin makes you fat in the real world? Well, a couple. What hold out a second? Why am I doing work on my computer? Windows suggests that I can explore Microsoft movies and TV watching anime, horror, action, and more. And it even asks me if I want to launch it now or later, Microsoft, you know where I want more of pop-ups. In any case, Microsoft, you're great. Last time I talked smack about Bill Gates, I got a muscle cramp on this very channel. I won't do that. All right, here we go. Observe problems. First, insulin usually doesn't raise hunger levels. Insulin spikes do that if you inject exogenous insulin. If you are producing endogenous insulin, which almost everyone who says that insulin causes fat is talking about endogenous internally produced insulin, and internally produced insulin seems to usually have a negative effect on hunger. It creates a feeling of fullness. It just doesn't reliably make you hungrier unless you get some really exotic conditions. So that whole idea of a insulin is how you get hungry all the time, just doesn't seem to be true. Second, we can test this hypothesis directly. The claim is that via the insulin mediated pathways, high carbohydrate diets, which make the secretion of lots of insulin and necessity, cause more fat gain. We could just go and test that out. Yet 20 people to eat high fat diets or low carbs, yet 20 people to eat high carb diets or low fats, and see who gets fat after three months. It turns out there's basically no difference. The all of the studies taken together of which there has been dozens and dozens of studies conducted in various ways, different designs, different populations. It turns out that if you keep calories roughly the same, the amount of fat lost, gained, or maintained is also roughly the same. Whether you eat a diet mostly of carbohydrates, mostly of fats, or anything in between. So it turns out that high insulin exposure versus low insulin exposure, high carb diets for low carb diets, don't predictably lead to any differences in weight gain or fat gain. That just dukes that hypothesis right out of the water. I mean, you can speculate all you want about the mechanisms, but if the thing you're speculating is simply not true in practice, you gotta take a step back and understand that you did something wrong. For example, if I can speculate that I can beat up Tyson Fury in a boxing match because of all kinds of theoretical reasons. You know, I'm probably stronger than Tyson Fury. Number one, let's talk about high fructose corn syrup actually is. We take corn starch, which comes from corn, which comes from America, which comes from God. Yep. And we break that down into glucose. And then we insert an enzyme called glucose isomerase. And it flips some of those glucosees into fructoses. And the result is two different kinds of chemicals. One is high fructose corn syrup 42, which has 42% of fructose and the rest in glucose. And then there's high fructose corn syrup 55, which is 55% of fructose from that process and the rest is glucose. Now, high fructose corn syrup 42 is typically used in baked goods. And then high fructose corn syrup 55 is typically used in soft drinks. Now, high fructose corn syrup, a HFCS 55 is 55% fructose 45% glucose in free form. Suque-rose normal sugar from canes or beets, which is what's put into a soda that the sugar cane soda, is 50% fructose 50% glucose, but they're bonded together not split apart. However, your intestinal sucrease enzymes that everybody has cleaves that bond in seconds. So by the time either high fructose corn syrup or natural natural sucrose is hitting the bloodstream both deliver almost the identical, almost the identical fructose to glucose ratio. So as far as your bloodstream and all the health effects that has is concerned, it's almost the same thing. Now, the thing is why do they use high fructose corn syrup for a few reasons? One of them is that high fructose corn syrup 55 stays liquid in room temperature dissolved in fluids, which is really handy for soda fountains and chewy snacks. Because regular sucrose can sometimes bunch up and then you get that sugar coating. It's got you ever have like open up some kind of drink and it's got like little sugar crispy on it and you're like, this, it just doesn't do that. So it's better, it makes more money, people like it better, etc. Now the metabolic bottom line here, differences between these two substances of regular sucrose and high fructose corn syrup, is that once they are absorbed the liver and the rest of your body, sees practically identical substrates and that 5% difference in extra fructose is basically biochemical trivia. It just doesn't seem to make a big difference in any measurable way, but do not take my word for it because there's a load of actual data. So let's get into that. This data set Scott you will like because it's not a hint. This is the, the sledgehammer of data. Check this out. The first thing I'm going to summarize is not the only thing. Is a meta analysis of the best kinds of studies randomized control trials. That's when they take groups of people, no one knows shit about what's going on. And one group has the same diet and has high fructose corn syrup in it and the other has the identical diet and has sucrose in it. Sometimes they switch groups halfway through the study and then switch back again. So this is the gold standard to actually assess cause and effect, not just correlation, this is causation. That's what a randomized control trial is. And since they just didn't want to do one, they did a meta analysis of 20 total randomized control trials. But these were short trials, right? Nope. The average length of each trial was 21 weeks. You would think they'd pick up something. Check this out. Hey folks, it's me, Dr. Mike, because we've had a science-purdization. Should you be concerned about insulin resistance? A GA lack of insulin sensitivity, if you are doing bodybuilding or muscle growth training or sports of any kind? So, first of all, what is insulin resistance? In this context we're talking mostly about what's called peripheral insulin resistance, it's generally when your muscle cells and your fat cells get worse at using insulin to transport glucose from the bloodstream into the cell interior itself. That's what insulin does. It's a transport facilitator. And as your insulin resistance goes up, the same amount of glucose doesn't shuttle through for the same amount of insulin use and you have to shoot more insulin into the bloodstream via the pancreas to get the same shuddling effect. This is not great for a few reasons. One is it tends to not fill up your cells with nutrients as much as it's bad to you. The second thing is generally speaking, as you develop insulin resistance, your muscle becomes more resistant to insulin before your fat cells. If you think of this through, that means some way on the way to insulin resistance, your muscles get really bad at absorbing the glucose that hugely stimulates in support type hypertrophy. Also, there's an insulin mediated transport of a bunch of amino acids as well. And also, insulin directly is an actual anabolic activator for a bunch of pathways in the cell and a huge activator of anticatabolism. So when insulin locks into its receptors, it actually tells the muscle cell to stop degrading its structure as much as normally does. If this isn't happening as much in muscle cells, you're going to be less prone to gain muscle and more prone to lose it. Well, at the same time, the fat cells are still fairly sensitive, which means all the stuff in your bloodstream that the insulin's not gobbling up to go into your muscle cells, it's more likely to go into your fat cells, which is a really bad deal. And just insulin resistance makes you less muscular and more fat. Holy shit, that's a bad deal. And after a while, if it happens for a long time, your pancreas produces more and more insulin to compensate because you can't get nutrients into the cells. Your body's pretty sensitive to that sort of thing. It starts to increase how much insulin, it shoots into the bloodstream to get this nutrients into the cells. And at some point, it can actually overstress the pancreas. It's trying to produce too much insulin. Andcreas decides to smoke its last cigarette and dive old age. And then you become diabetic. Formally, you get type two diabetes. And that's very, very bad for you. Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for RP Strength and High reps are better for cutting. What is it like a hook? Is this a myth? Nope, I actually mean this. Here's what I'm saying. When you are in a fat loss phase in your physique training, you might want to consider biasing your rep ranges a little bit more into the 10 to 20 range or even the 15 to 20 range and bias it a little less on average and most lift away from the 5 to 10 rep range and especially away from the 3 to 5 rep range. Now you've probably heard this before, high reps are better than cutting type of stuff. And you might have even heard of a few reasons why, but the problem is that many most of the reasons you've heard before are total BS nonsense. There are good reasons that exist. Most of the reasons you've heard are the bad reasons. So let's look at some of the common ones that are just non-starters. First, let us know in the comments if you've heard these before, or even heard some that we're not going to list here. Some people claim that high reps toned the muscle instead of bulking it. Here's what toning is. A reduction in fat which occurs outside of the muscle, or an increase in muscle size or some combination of both. There is nothing that happens to the muscle per se other than growing it or shrinking it that is anything like toning. It's a magical transmutation of muscle or fat. It's a real simple. There's two tissues, muscle and fat, decreased fat, increased muscle, that's toning. Some combination of those two. Toning is not a thing that you do with different reps. It's a barely even a cogent concept. Bulking a muscle versus toning a muscle is some shit they told women in the 1990s so that it didn't get scared away from lifting weights. Another one you might have heard is that high reps increased muscle definition by carving the strations in there. Scott, have you heard that one etching in the detail? Oh yes, there is absolutely no mechanism by which this happens. If you strip away the fat your muscle is exactly as straight as it will ever be it can just get bigger or smaller. And why wouldn't low reps etch the strations, which isn't a thing, any better than high reps, it's nonsense from start to finish. If someone tells you this in the gym, just smile and not go, dough, I quit that hard you feel me and you walk that L away forever from that very nice person. Another thing that some of these that I was reviewing and I sent a chatchupetean a fact-finding mission to tell me some other stuff from its huge corpus of training and some of these I'm like, whoa, I haven't heard these in a long time but I absolutely remember hearing them as far back as in the 90s. Some people still talk in that ish. High reps keep the muscle smaller and more compact so that you don't get bulky. Here's the problem with that. We have unbelievably convincing research to show that anywhere between five reps and about 30 reps as long as the set gets close to failure cause exactly the same amount of muscle growth set for set. So if you're doing high reps and Scott, I've legitimately seen women do like very hard sets of 15 and then straight up tell me after that they don't want to get bulky that's why they don't do sets of five which is like it is especially funny thing to see. However, there are actually good reasons not a ton of them but these are reasons that are compelling enough for me to make a whole video for you guys and for Scott and Max to edit it in a whole thing because it does make a difference at the margins and you probably should be doing slightly higher reps during your fat loss phases. Here are some of the most convincing reasons. When you are using lower loads, lighter weights which in order to get close to failure you have to do for higher reps to keep the sets effective, you have less acute injury risk. On rack your 5 RM from the squat from the bench in the deadlift etc. weighted pull up the your probability of getting hurt during any one of those sets is way higher than if you un-rack your 15 or your 20 RM period. That does not mean the absolute risk of injury is high any to one of those cases. Good technique, well-controlled, accustomed sets of 5 are very safe. They're safe for them almost every sport you could ever play unit of time for unit of time spent in the gym. But comparing apples to apples, heavier weights have a more likely probability of getting hurt acutely that is in the set how you're playing something and then that's it. You're not training for two weeks, then lighter weights done for higher reps and it's just a matter of force transduction through tendons. It's just really not complicated. It's literally the same mechanism by which asking the question of like, hey, if you get into a car accident at 15 miles an hour, what's the probability you're really hurt versus if you get into car accident at 30 miles an hour or 45 miles an hour, just more acute force means higher probability of something catastrophic happening. And again, this isn't car accidents, this is lifting very low absolute risk. But the relative risk is absolutely higher. Good God, I should have said that. It's a stupid way. It's got the relative risk is absolutely higher. Good job, Mike. The relative risk is definitely higher for heavier weights than for lighter weights, for lower reps than for higher reps. And with lower loads used for higher reps, there's less chronic wear and tear on your connective tissues because your connective tissues heal slower than your muscles do. Your tendons and the appernorosis that connects your tendons to your muscles take on damage as well as your muscles do, but muscles are very well profused with blood flow, tendons not nearly as much. And for a few other reasons, tendons in a connective tissue between the tendons and the muscle takes longer to heal between bouts of training and accumulates more damage over time than muscles. Now, if you were in a blocking phase or maintenance phase, you have plenty of food and plenty of rest, your fatigue isn't sky high. And you're generally able to recover from low reps just fine. So the acute injury risk is also modified by fat loss phase in an interesting way, because I just said lower loads have lower acute injury risk. But what the hell does that have to do with bulking and cutting? During bulking, it's more likely you'll get hurt from heavier weights. During cutting, it's more likely you get hurt from heavier weights. So like what gives, why are we separating the two? Because a higher fatigue state is a known thing that has to happen during a fat loss phase because extra calories bring down fatigue. This higher accumulated degree of fatigue has many consequences, some of them very subtle, and one of the most interesting findings in sports science is that athletes who exhibit a high level of fatigue lose a bit of motor fluidity, gross motor fluidity, their athleticism is lower. They have butter fingers, and their movements aren't as fluid and they don't make the micro adjustments to make the movement have as good of technique. If you're going light and high rep, all right, whatever, fine, not ideal technique, a little bit of a jumpy cut-out situation, no big deal. But if you're using heavy weights and you're doing lower reps, and your technique is off even a little bit, it could be a bad, bad deal. So generally the idea is you want to lift your heaviest when your fatigue is the lowest because you'll do the best performance and because your probability of injuries going to be lower. If you have a higher degree of fatigue than the real situation is that if you go heavier, you'll probably be okay. But because you're less athletic, and your technique isn't a smooth, the probability that you'll make enough of a technique faux pas to cause an acute injury goes up, not by a lot, but here's the thing, towards the end of the fat loss phase. That's when shit really matters. That's when you don't want to break your heart and maintenance phase, whatever you take some time off, you get back on, nothing happened. And in addition to that higher fatigue from just having that caloric deficit and having to stay there for a while, by both caloric deficit mechanism and independent fatigue mechanism, what ends up happening is your muscle fibers convert over that course of the fat loss phase slightly into their slower twitch variants from faster twitch to slower twitch, which means two things. One, your ability to lift for strength, your ability to progress in the lower reps, putting on weight on the bar, declines. That sucks. Progression wise, it can throw you off, but really you just do more volume in your fine, but motivation wise, it can really throw you off. As that's happening for you, your slow twitch fibers are better at endurance. And the more slow twitch they get as you train them, the better they are at doing reps. And because we have actually researched that I was a part of publishing to really good data to show that increasing reps over the course of multiple months, so long as you don't get way over 30 reps, causes the same overload stimulus and growth as increasing weight on the bar. You have a big unlock. If during a fat loss phase, you go from doing sets of 10 with the same weight to doing sets of 15, it gives you both progression and higher reps. And you're able to add reps during a fat loss phase for two reasons. One, your fibers are slower twitch and they're literally have more endurance. And more endurance every week. And in addition to that, as you shrink down your fat stores, you get more endurance because the systemic drag of your fat ass on the rest of your body declines. You guys have noticed how in a peak bulk, thick boy phase, you do a set of 10 on the leg press and you're throwing up in your out of breath, whereas at the end of a cut when you're nice and lean, you do a set of 15 on the leg press and you're like, oh, I can just do another set in 30 seconds. No problem. Those two factors combine to make progression on weight, adding weight week after week after week in your fat loss phase, really hard in demotivating. But progression on reps might actually be so good that it counter balances that high fatigue state. It might even counter balance the muscle loss so that it's least psychologically, you're continuing to hit PRs or at least not losing strength. Because of that, rep progressions and because you're better at higher reps, choosing to do higher reps or even increase your reps as the cutting phase progresses is a very swell idea to consider. Each training principle is applied to this set of exercises. Then we apply the next training principle and it knocks out a bunch that don't meet the muster and the circle of exercises gets smaller and smaller and smaller until we have just a few exercises which are our best and then we can use those. Today's tip is about how to maximize the effectiveness of your chest training, with a really cool cue that I use that is basically reaching out and up with your chest. So here's the deal. When you're doing chest presses of any kind, push ups, dumbbells, barbells, machines, rings, anything in between. What you're trying to do ideally, in most cases is really stimulate your chest as much as possible. Oh, my chest bounced at that. It's just getting excited. And it pays to make sure that when you're going through this difficult lifting and you're trying a lot and you bother to warm up and come to the gym and everything, you might as well maximize that technique to get as much stimulus for the pacts as possible. So it's not just a matter of moving the weights up and down. And the thing is, is if you lie down on a bench press or a machine or anything like that, you sit down and you sit down flat with your shoulders forward and you do some pressing, your anterior deltoids and your triceps, if you have certain genetics, especially can get in a lot of those stimulus, a lot of the work and actually become limiting factors. Such at every, after every single set of presses, you're kind of like, oh yeah, my pecs got a little bit, I think, but my fan adults are just pumped beyond belief. My triceps are already like shaky and almost sore now. What am I doing these presses for? And can I do presses in a way that maximally stimulates my chest? And the answer is yes, and here it is. The best technique for pressing for most people, barbell, dumbbell, machine, anything is as the machine or bar implement or whatever descends or as an push up you descend, you want to reach up and out with your chest. And a part of that up and out motion is going to have you retracting your scapula, a, your shoulder blades back. It's like one of my friends way back in high school termed the funky pigeon. It's like pigeons log around like this all the time. Oh, I just accidentally did a Greg DeSatron Prussian. Scott, the video I love that one. So if you put your chest up, stick it out by arching her back a little bit and then having your scabs back, as you descend, you've already pre-stretched your pecs, which means they're going to get a really big stimulus the deeper that you go. At the bottom of the movement, let's say that it's a barbell bench press for simplicity. You're thinking as much about lowering the bar to your chest at the very bottom, as you are with your hip stationary on the bench, no butt wiggling, reaching up with your chest as much as possible to meet the bar on the way down. It's not you bring the bar down completely. Most of the movement is, the very bottom interest, so you reach, you're already reaching the whole time. You reach extra really, get your chest up to touch the bar. That reaching pre-structures the pecs, while at the same time putting them as the most limiting factor position in the lift. What you want to think about is exposing your chest. If you come down like this and you're all contorted, your scabs are forward, your back is flat, your shoulders are front. Your chest is kind of pointed down, you're hiding your chest. If I was benching with an injury, I would do that. Hey folks, it's Dr. Mike for Renaissance Parasization. Welcome to the Targeting Muscle Series. Today's muscle is the back muscle, plural. And the exercise is the barbell bent over row. We're going to give you a few tips and tricks to get you to feel the barbell bent row more in the part of your back that you want. Let's get started. Alright folks, so the first big tip for properly bent rowing and getting your back to actually get a hit is the practice of hinging into the movement versus bending into the movement. So if you just bend over, notice my rounded lower back and you do bent rows like that's cool. Your arms are moving, your back is ostensibly pulling them sweet. The problem is that as soon as you round your spine, two things happen. One, you're pulling muscles get much weaker because any time your back is rounded, the central drive coming from your brain through your spinal cord reduces because your body thinks it's not state nor safe. You can't literally row as much with your back if you round your back then if you keep your back flat. The second thing is that back rounding means that the spinal ractor muscles have to work for a much more stretched position and mechanically disadvantage of position. They have to try a lot harder to make sure you don't like pop your vertebrae out of your asshole or whatever they do if they turn off. So because your lower back muscles are always in a poor position, they tend to be the thing that gives out first. So if you're trying to train your spinal ractors at a lengthened isometric position while pretending to train your rest of your pulling muscles, that's a great way to bend row. Ideally what you want to do is give a challenge to your spinal ractors. Something they may not get on a chest supporter row, which also want to put them and the back into the most mechanically favorable position that allows all the other muscles to come close to failure and gives you a really strong launch point for being able to really contract those muscles. So instead of bending over, you shouldn't be event overall, being super-natic, you should be a hinge row. You do as you basically do this to flick a deadlift down to the bar. Notice my tummy's out. The back is nice and tight. I've hinged using my hips, not my back. My back is straight. My spinal ractors are strong. I grab the bar. Hey folks, it's me, Dr. Mike, for NSW and on today's high-perchography myths series episode, we'll be talking about over-valuing the mind muscle connection. That is, mind muscle connection is more important than everything else. We'll talk about what the myth is. Talk about some of the good points it makes, some of the bad, which is why it's a myth, and a little bit of real talk at the end to make sure we're on the same page as to what actually works well. So, this idea that the mind muscle connection is ultra-altern important is not just something that we have observed, people sort of say they say it rather directly. This is something I've heard many times, read in muscle magazines, seen in YouTube videos, an Instagram post by professional bodybuilder sometimes, is that you have to focus on the muscle and don't worry about the weights or the reps. Another thing people say is bodybuilding is about making lightweight, seem heavy. It sounds like some voodoo, something cool. You're exactly why that's a good thing, but it has something to do with how your muscle is sort of exposed to the weight. And a lot of people will say, look, don't chase PRs. Don't worry about how strong you are, just make sure that you focus on the working muscle, and that's all you need. Now, there are some good silver linings in there. One is that a strong mind muscle connection properly done can enhance the muscle growth potential of a lift, specifically with respect to the muscle that you are focusing on. Like triceps and a skull crusher, for example. They're way too a skull crusher, we have no idea what the triceps is doing, that aren't ideal for triceps hypertrophy, but if you really clue in on the right stuff about what the tricep is doing, you can alter the technique and alter the execution of the lift, such that it actually helps triceps grow more. So there's definitely something there. In addition to that sort of expanding on it, your technique and an exercise can be really helped by paying attention to what the muscle is doing, not just moving from point A to point B. For example, if you do some kind of pressing movement on a machine, cable, dumbbells, barbell, whatever, if you just press up and down, that's cool. But you may feel like, oh yeah, like my pecs, if you pay attention to your pecs, you're doing it, okay, they're contracting, they're stretching fine. But if you arch your back and you retract your shoulder blades and then you do it press, you guided by my muscle will be like, wow, this really does seem to hit the pecs much more. In every single exercise, there are ways of slightly altering the movement that will give you more of a feel in the muscle that you're trying to work. And other ways that will give you less of one. And if you follow the technical hints at more of the ways that help the muscle work more, you're going to have a better time, you're going to be able to do more of the work for that muscle and get better results. By doing that, you're lifting the same weight, same reps, but you're doing it in a technique that is guided by the mind muscle connection by your perception of what's going on with a target muscle on the one extreme, it's like, I have no idea what I'm packs you're doing, don't care on the other hand, it's like your mind is in the pec, your brain is a giant pec. could've said that better. And so I was touching my knee to the ground but it was quick and the descent was quick and the stance wasn't as wide because I was falling into that thing of how do I lift the most weight and impress myself with a highest number of reps with a given heavy weight? And I paid for it with an injury and then after that I cleaned up my lunges and my glutes only ever got bigger because I started taking longer steps, sinking slower in, doing slightly higher reps and really shifting my weight to my front foot, which was a trick I only learned like 20 years later when I was training with Jared Feather. If you take all of that into consideration, think the big lesson is this, anytime you are working for physique like you want to be your most jacked and there is an exercise that you could do yellow style like let's go have you in scling and bang or you could do it controlled style. Really the only thing you have to ask is just two questions. One is one of these is going to get me better gains and the answer is no they both work for roughly equivalent gains and two, which one is statistically more likely to get me hurt and it's clanging and banging by a long shot. And so then you end up doing the slower, more controlled reps, not super slow but control and super deep and a big stretch, nothing crazy explosive, not because you think that's going to get you more jacked, it's not yellow lifting, it's really jacked. In any case, it is my rep match sets. Some of you may have heard of them. Please help in the comments to describe to people who have questions then. Some have not. What are they? So we're familiar with my reps. And my reps, invented by better gay, faggurally, I think I said that mostly okay. He's from Norway. He's got a funny Norwegian name. It's a form of rest-pause training where you do a set of 10 to 20 repetitions pretty close to failure. You rest for 0, 3 to 5 seconds or something like that. Sometimes even 5 to 10. And then you continue doing a few more little mini sets called my rep sets where you get just 5 to 10 reps and then another 5 to 10 reps, then another 5 to 10 reps, you can do one more of these sets or two or three even four of them. What they do is because you come close to failure on the first set, you can start the next set in a pre-fatee state and get more failure approaches without having to do as many what are called lead in reps. And this is a pretty good way of training in many instances and something I use a bunch. But here's a limitation of my repsets. Typically what's going to happen is you're going to do one of these where you do 10 to 20 sets and then another set of 8 to another set of 6 and another set of 5 and then you're done with little mini breaks in between. And then like that's what you do for the exercise. And that's totally cool but you may need more volume, more stimulus because some muscles particularly ones that are smaller and that's need to be bigger and are very fatigue resistant and hypertrophy resistant that just don't grow much just a few my repsets or four sets of 10 or 12 is just not driving enough disruption and enough growth. If that's the case you can pull a rabbit out of a hat and do my rep match sets and here's what they look like. The ultimate guide to what range of motion you should be using is the stimulus to fatigue ratio. Does it? The exercise in that range of motion give you a ton of perceived tension in that muscle. Does it give you a burn at higher reps in that muscle? Does it give you a pump in that muscle after a few sets? Does it give you soreness and disruption in that muscle and weakness in that muscle after a few sets and maybe a day later? On the other hand, does it hurt the joints in connective tissues? It doesn't just completely exhaust your whole body or is it pretty kind to them. Stimulus on that top side fatigue on the bottom side, divide the two into each other and you get the stimulus to fatigue ratios. The more you can get a big hit with tension, burn, pump, soreness, etc. And the last joint in connective tissue disruption can impose and less systemic fatigue and impose, the better. So if you pick a standardized range of motion and you do it and it's got a really good stimulus to fatigue ratio, maybe you try going a little deeper and it hasn't even better stimulus to fatigue ratio, for example, if you bench press with a regular barbell and the definition stops at your chest. You may at some point have access to either dumbbells or even better a cambered bar that has a big open middle space and you can get to blow your chest to for a really nasty stretch. Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for Renaissance Pre-Dization. Today's weekly tip is don't chase progressions too much. What? But I thought we were supposed to be progressing. What is too much progress? Is that even a thing? Turns out yes. So are you supposed to hit PRs in the gym? PR by a rep here by five pounds here? Yes, absolutely. The core of the training process is to add reps and or load to the bar weekly, de-load repeat. However, that should not, cannot come at the expense of very good technique because if you have to get a rep with bad technique, you're lying to yourself about the progress that you're really making, which could be no progress or much less than you think you are. So if you're supposed to hit 10 reps on a squat, but you hit 12, hey PR, but the last two reps were total dog shit. Maybe you could have only hit 11 with a technique. So maybe 12 is an exaggeration. Next week, you're going to want to PR again. You're going to want to hit 13 reps, but you're going to only do 11. So you're just incrementally adding shitty reps to the end of your sets. No way, no. What you're at. End up doing is all of the training that you're doing if PRs are everything and you let your technique degrade at first and then try to match PRs after that. You get a real degradation of your stimulus of a T-raceo, which means that all of the work you do in the weeks after you hit a fake PR and try to match it, the stimulus is lower than how high the fatigue is because in order to grind out reps, you usually have to break their technique. You're not hitting the target muscles as much anymore. For example, in squats, you should be failing at your quads, but now you're trying to round your back and can't leave for you but up, and it's more glute training than you needed. It's more lower back training than you needed. It's a lot of systemic fatigue and your quads aren't getting any better of a workout because you're actually trying to avoid having them be the limiting factor. No good, no good, no good. So when you settle in for a hard set, yes, you should have your goal reps in mind. Okay, I want to get 13 reps, but every reps should be treated as its own with stellar technique every single time. And if you are unable to repeat two reps in a row with good technique, the set is over. If you underperform, that's okay. You can make up for it on the next set because performance is an average of all the sets of the exercise. If you underperform two sessions in a row, then you're just too fatigued to hit the PRs and it's time for a deal. No big deal. Remember, most times you're not progressing because you will the progress. Sometimes you have to have a lot of willpower to get to the progress that you need. However, most other times progress is just something that happens when you apply your willpower to getting good technique and seeing how many good technique reps you can get because if you get a lot of good technique, good technique reps more than last time than you've progressed. But if with good technique, you can't get the reps you're supposed to. You're not progressing your two fatigue. It's time to deal with this just no wrong answer. There, the honest with yourself always is good technique. And yes, try to hit the big PRs, but never at the expense of technique. Ever, ever, ever, ever, ever. And if you do it, you're terrible and you should be crying yourself to sleep every night. See you guys next time.
